Entry.1:
Went Cairo for Remounts & in to dinner at Shepherds. With a good bed & decent Tucker a man soon puts on condition again. I lost 1½ stone with the cold etc at Gallipoli.

YMCA here is a great boon to the soldiers, attended service- wrong again should be Sunday We had a horse running today in Overseas Handicap- at Gezerah had a lot of fun but lost our Pennies - there are some good Arab Stallions around Cairo.

Took Mardi & Lorna Cooke Tun Ware & a chap called Haines for a ride- all flourishing-

Sorry to hear A.J. Austin’s death, must write Harry Rec’d Mother’s letter Nov 26 & yes I got pips from You may address me as Captain now -Sheepskin waistcoat arrived per post Rev Rogers yet. A lot of old papers are also being delivered now. Many thanks for all Also cable from 

I bought a Palm leaf bed on arrival & have just discovered BUGS galore it seems impossible to soldier without vermin- I’m back to Mother earth again.
Entry.2:
Went Alexandria to see about Brigade Baggage in Anzac- A good train runs & a Hamper can be ordered en route so I travelled 
in
 de luxe The delta is all green now with growing crops- Found the wharfs covered with Kits, Guns, Rifles, etc etc, & after sorting thro’ large quantities found a few Signal Troop Baskets of Lamp Helios etc:- Much Baggage had been broken & looted en route all jumbled up together & lying in Pools of Water, as it has rained all day. 

I do not expect to find any of mine, I am getting too old a soldier to worry about Kit now, Cut the loss & buy some more & be thankful you have your own carcase.
Entry.3:
Stayed at Windsor Hotel the old Hall Porter bemoans the lack of Tourists- which were worth 250/- /- a year to him.

All the survivors of the SS Persia, which was torpedoed are staying here men, women & children, they are fairly cheerful but lost everything & most of them had been picked up out of the water. Returned Cairo 4 p.m. train.

Cutter is here & well.
Entry.4:
Regimental Drill mounted & in afternoon went No.1 Hospital to get a tooth fixed up- There I met Riley from Deniliquin.

Did I tell you Norman (G Robertson & his wife is here as Dr in the 1st L.H. Field Ambulance 

Cold today & raining part of the 2" we get in the year. 

 We will not be leaving here for a week yet so post this with love
Entry.5:
Cold here now & it would be Blizzard at Anzac. Please thank Day for Bed soks & May for her Parcel; all received safely.

Had 2 teeth filled today.

Busy getting Squadron equipped & ready to move any moment 

 Now that we are reforming men & officers are turning up from all points of the Compass They kept quiet while a Winter at Gallipoli was expected & enjoyed themselves in England & Scotland- All ranks say they have been treated like princes in the old country
Entry.6:
Captain of the day today so I have little time to self day or night.

Cold nights beautiful sharp days – plenty of good tucker & no SHELLS.

Drilling each day on the Desert like long ago but many familiar faces are missing-
Entry.7:
Went Cairo Pay Office on Reg. Buisness- The Rabbits I cultivated ere I went to Anzac are still about the Camp notwithstanding several Mongoose or should it be Mongeese which were once imported into Australia with the idea of Killing the Pest. Here the mongoose is fairly numerous I once found one in a Rabbit Pit outback.

I believe there is good snipe & Duck shooting where we are going I wish I had my gun, as there will be no Turkey shooting for sometime.
Entry.8:
Day hot again at No.1 Took Mardi & Miss Cook for a ride out on the Desert as we do not now march for a day or two- 

Both girls are well & take a great interest in their work. They were lucky to get to Cairo before the embargo on Women folk.

Monday January 10 1916

Leave today for Dentist. Rev Rogers sent me a wire he was coming to Camp so I waited to see him glad to hear all D’quin news.

Sent Leather Kit B/gs (2)

1 Armenian oil cloth Pkge
Entry.9:
Wooden c/- Sword’s Saddlery

Went Shepheards to Dinner with White (Capt)

Rev Rogers delivered letter Pad thank you very much for sending, he seems a good fellow
Entry.10: Cairo for dinner & then to the Kuisaal with some of the old 6th L.H. The Kuisaal is a variety show not unlike the Tivoli.
Entry.11:
today Letter from Laura & Charlie all seemed well-

Posted you some verses written by a Bushie now in the Pay office, being wounded too badly for further Trench work- It is the high qualities of the Rank & file which keep our Regiments going & I always feel how extra good the officers 
should be
 to lead such men-

Anticipated being away ere this but here we are still as no water available at our outpost at present.

Climate is lovely here, now warm days & cold nights.
Entry.12:
Letter from Kathleen of Nov 24 Daisy & Mother Dec 5th

Hear that Hellas was successfully evacuated but we get little reliable news.
Entry.13:
Marched out at 6 A.M. for 
"Barrage"
 where we had camped before last April the prettiest spot in Egypt. A 25 mile Trek made some of the horses sore & tired Fully equipped in full marching order is very different to riding in a stripped saddle minus Rifle ammunition etc :- One troop has hurried on to Patrol a fresh water Canal feeding Alexandria from the Senuses who are gathering in numbers with some guns captured from the Italians on our West.

Camel Corps is travelling with us & horses never seem to get used to Camels
Entry.14:
Arrived 
Wardan
 & one troop marched on 35 miles. Of course it rained just enough to wet us through it always does this when shifting Camp.

South of us is a Petrified Forest evidence of different climatic & physical conditions in the past The only roads in the Desert are Camel Tracks & they represent the shortest distances between Water.
Entry.15:
All hands working laying troughing, putting down horse lines (difficult in the sand) & trying to find Regimental baggage sent by rail. This is a Godforsaken sandy place, but better than the Peninsular & Soldiers would not be happy if they did not growl

We evidently will have our Base here for some time with trips into the Desert with Camels.

Hardly any trace of yesterdays rain, Sand blowing in Clouds again. 

Good for sore eyes, all the Arabs are afflicted with a sort of blight, & the Flies made them look pleasant.
Entry.16:
Capt of Day.

Sand 2 ft deep Tent pegs won’t hold, Camel Corps passed & frightened all the Horses which pulled up the Lines Could hardly see for dust The Tucker saved from 

Xmas parcels & Billies came in most handy, as no fires could be lit. A regular Darling Show only worse

It is all Desert here a few Hares & Gazelles & plenty of Camels. Scorpions are fairly numerous but few men get bitten.

The Horses are small & wiry & are accustomed to go for 2 days without WATER.
Entry.17:
The Water here is obtained from 4 sources-

1. One is a Cistern built by the Romans & dependent on the rainfall, cannot be relied on & is very hard to find 

2. Underground springs deep & requiring proper pumping appliances.

3. Sand Wells like Riverina (4) unreliable small supply.

Went Cairo per horse & Train a long wearisome journey on duty for missing Equipment & paid 10 PT = 2/s for a Bath on arrival- Sore lips & sore eyes from the drifting sand
Entry.18:
Posted this 
yes
 today from Cairo-

Love to all-

On my way back to the Desert again
Entry.19:
Returned yesterday to the Desert with a Truck of Baggage as far as Wardan- expect it will be sometime ere I leave again for civilization.

The Bedouin Arabs we hope to fight are nomadic Tribes from the deserts, with one or two seaports on the Mediteranean These towns are just Oasis with a population of a few 1000 living on Camels meat Fowls, eggs, barley etc The tracks across the desert are shown by stone cairns & the Camel pads

A few old Roman cisterns contain water after rain. One spot we saw 2 native women making Butter in a Goat skin.
Entry.20:
Beautiful days & cold frosty nights bright starlight & endless desert very like Western NSW in Winter.

 Omit :

 Received mails more regularly now- letters from Mother Dec.3 Nyle Ritchie same date , also papersMy address is now Capt. A Squadron, 
not
 Head Quarters 
now
 

The good folk at home should send NO more Winter clothing or Soks for some time the men have plenty & by the time this is received & answered say 2 months, the Winter will be over & the heat begun again.

People have been wonderfully good at sending us Soldiers Comforts
Entry.21:
This side of the Wardan railway in years gone by had been cultivated a little but the Desert has triumphed in the end & covered everything even the railway has to be protected by fencing Further out on the Desert the going is hard & the surface covered with small stones but transport once off the road has to be done by Camels

Roads are made by laying Bulrushes & reeds from the Nile first then manure and rubbish – better roads are macadamised but the stone has to be railed a long way & then per camel. We hear that the 3rd Regiment has had a bit of a scrap with the Bedouins, but news is unreliable-
Entry.22:
Church Service today by Rev Capt Gordon a first rate Padre I think Dean of Goulburn. I could not help thinking how much better our men look as Troopers with leather equipment riding Pants, leggings & Spurs instead of the Permanent rig-out of the Infantry. It is hard work to make the average Bushmen march he slouches along with head down, but on a horse looks comfortable so different again to the Tommies who bump along

Cold frosty night again & Days bed soks 
were
 are a great success-

Volunteers are asked for the Camel Corps, many of our men have offered- in ignorance a good deal, but distant fields etc .
Entry.23:
Mrs Wilkinsons woollen helmet or whatever it was hasn’t arrived at least not yet-

Young Allanson came to see me re transfer into combatant Reg instead of A. Medical Corps so am trying to get him into 
Life very tame
 1st L.H. 

Life fairly tame here, we here 5000 Senussis are about 30 miles West but nothing doing so far.

We will all be a bit old fashioned when we get back to civilization & not know the latest Fox Trot or Hesitation Waltz, but perhaps our partners will excuse us.

Picket talked so much owing to the cold, I got up & dressed thinking Reveille had gone instead it was 2.30, I sent the whole picquet to a hot place
Entry.24:
We have a Welsh Cavalry Regiment near here, mounted on Bob-tailed Suffolk Punch sort of Chargers & the Tommies bump along, much to the amusement of our men on their long tailed Australian ‘horses, which stand out above anything I have seen over here- notwithstanding the Patriots who gave all their buck jumping, bridle breaking rogues from each district. There should be no outlaws left in the back country at all now.

Today such a Blizzard & Khamsin, Darling Shower blew the sun was put out with sand 
&
 with head down one bumped into others if one moved about & the water holes were filled with sand, teeth, eyes, ears & Tucker all sand- Much joy in the land of Camels
Entry.25:
The natives are very shy out here & at sunset string in to water each leading an animal a lamb to a Camel-

Women are never seen between the ages of 8 or 80, they appear to be kept in absolute seclusion. Field Officer today, this is the work of a Major, but Captains do it- practically Orderly Officer to the Brigade.

What women we do see are very modest!! & generally wear only one garment, so when they unexpectedly meet a European they throw this over their head feeling sure they have done the correct thing, but the rest of their body does not even boast a fig leaf-
Entry.26:
Our Officers Mess is using nothing but Primus stoves, hardly wood enough is carted for the men-

First 3 hours last night going round outposts cold & wet.

Very easy to get twisted on a dark night-

"Senusseis" are mounted on Camels & they make no sound on the Desert with their big soft padded feet.

Posted some Postcards in book form yesterday 

Recd.- letter Mother & Day December 19- written as we were leaving ANZAC 

 Many of the lost men From Anzac missed getting their Billies I am seeing what can be done as many surplus are in Egypt-
Entry.27:
I hope ere this Friday Mother has gone South & Day too if it can be arranged; in easy stages our Mother must be much stronger now, thank goodness Omit

Tins of Kearnigs Powder from arrived tonight, here we are able to keep comparatively clean-

On the salt Lakes & away on the Nile Valley, there are Plover Duck & Snipe, but the Sheiks or Chiefs of friendly natives say if we fire one shot the natives will all clear 
ed
 out, they are so shy & frightened, that something dreadful is going to happen 12 Bore Cartridges at 20 shilling a 100 can be bought, but guns are scarce.
Entry.28: A Welsh mounted Regiment is near us & I expected to see some good Welsh Ponies, but the Horses are all a Suffolk Punch type Tails cut off & the Tommies ride mostly at a jig jog or trot, they never seem to make a horse walk decently or Canter.
Entry.29:
"Dates" are now being issued in lieu of jam, this may be good tucker for the Arabs & Bedouins but the meat eating Bushie does not take to vegetarian diet.

Today we hear of a bit of a rumpus in Cairo owing to Gyppy Reserve Soldiers being called up for service. The 9th L.H. went in & soon quietened with the aid of Machine guns in armoured cars- etc:- No place for women here at present Omit.

Attended Church Parade- We have now a fine fat Priest attached to the Regiment in addition to C. of E.
Entry.30:
Letter from Mother & Joe written on Xmas day so that is not bad
 I should have called but guessed the Papers would let you know we had left ANZAC.

We are expecting Gen Birdwood here this afternoon he is a popular Officer with the Australians & N. Zealanders & we all recognise he got us away from ANZAC very cleverly.

Will post these notes with love to all it is great luck to think all my notes have reached you & of late, your letters have also been delivered most regularly.
Entry.31:
(First paragraph largely indecipherable) Guns don’t interest me like they used to do, do you remember when X Omit

Here there is no fighting only training the new men in Outpost work & Advance Guards etc absolutely different to the old trench life.

X Had a letter from Laura & note Charlie is to get 6 weeks leave, what date does he come of age ? Omit
Entry.32:
I don’t know whether you realise the difficulty of writing up each day. Some days Fountain Pen won’t work then I use Pencil & hope you can read & after all it is a pleasure to let you know my daily life & its little enough . 

 

Thank Joe for sending I am nearly alright again. The Plaster I must have mislaid never mind 

I don’t think you need worry about the Turks beating us on the Canal it is nearly as tough a proposition as our try at the Dardanelles.

Joe mentions Cornolla sold but he does not say who to?
Entry.33:
Had a Field Day & like last summer a good deal of pretence at fighting. One bridge over a Canal was supposed to be blown up & the Tommie Sentry blocked a L.H. Trooper Scout from going across it.

So he tied his clothes on the Saddle took off his boots & with the reins in his teeth swinging his arms as swimming & yelling out, 
walked
 over, saying –"the bridge is blown up" & I’m swimming alright."

All this is to keep men & Horses fit while we wait for the attacks that never come. Men soon get stale & we I want a football badly- but by the time it could arrive, we will be fighting again in Ernest.
Entry.34:
We seem to spend a lot of £. S D. nearly all goes in Tucker 
but I’m not in debt like many Officers
 Cairo was an expensive place.

Here in camp there is no amusement when Patrols & Field Days are over, tried to buy a Football but there was not one in all Cairo.

Talking with a native who spoke English today he wanted to know how long the mares reared their foals as our Horses were so BIG compared to Egyptian Horses. The Arabs have a custom of carrying their foals in their arms as soon as born & then the Colt is never frightened & knows the smell of a man.
Entry.35:
Camels on the Right of us

Camels all around us- from Tawny Blacks to light fawns, this is the Camel Corps of enemy 1000s & our horses are more accustomed to them now.

On the Desert, they blend into a perfect protective color & when lying down are hard to see on the march so much daylight shows under them they look all legs like a centipede. Some are savage, but most of them were broken in. At night their legs are tied like a sheeps & then on to a ring in the ground "Tiboui" or "Barley" straw or Maize is just put in a shallow basin hollowed out in the sand.
Entry.36:
Church Parade good sermon always by C of E Padre Not far off a Native road maker was also praying looking towards Mecca they bow & touch the ground with their heads repeating the Koran, this they do 3 times a day generally just as you want their services.

Heard today that we are likely to go to 
Mersa Matrue
, up along the Mediteranean for some distance towards 
Tripoli
- via 
Alexandria
-

Letter from Lorna tonight all well with her & hers

We also have a Priest from Belgium a most interesting Padre, who knows Father O’ Connell & has been all over Australia he is a good Sport, & soldier.
Entry.37:
Exchanging Transport Horses for mules to go to 
"Mersa Matru"
 as all sandy tracks & little feed.

This Regiment or rather those whoever at ANZAC missed getting any Billies-but one turned up addressed to an Officer of A Squadron- Contents looked like sausages so last night these were cooked with mashed sweet potatoes & Worcester Sauce, but on getting to work the sausages panned out to be Plum Pudding put into Sausage Skins- We are tuckering well here, but it will be Bully Beef & Biscuit again soon.

A travelling kitchen is the best present for any rich man to give to a Regiment
Entry.38:
New moon & with 2 bright stars form the emblem of Egypt on Flags etc. (See images for diagram) lovely starlit nights.

I suppose it will be a case of going out back again if a man pulls through this affair.

The Illustrated London News 1/1/16 gives good picture of No.1 Outpost which we held to the last & I of that last at ANZAC. As I read more about it I realize how lucky we were to get off.
Entry.39:
A draft of 40 men arrived today to fill the places of sick men

 

since we left the Aerodrome Camp.

The leakage & waste even here is tremendous & a man is lucky to keep fit & well.

One man of our field Ambulance died lately of Cerebro Spinal Meningitis I suppose brought from Australia.

Mumps & Pneumonia & Measles claim most at present, but as a whole we are a healthy crowd & plenty of good Tucker for we Officers cooked on a Primus stove – as no wood on the Desert & the issue is all used by the men
Entry.40:
We asked some of the 
Welch
 Welsh Officers to Mess last night as a rule we get on
 well with
 the Regular Officers 

 

but the very fresh Kitcheners Army Officers are a supercilious lot & look upon us as "Beastly Colonials", of course our men do SKITE a bit & our Officers are not all one could always wish but alongside the Tommy counter jumper we can hold our own. They never speak to us in Tram or Train & I suppose when the war is over would not recognise us at all 

Why do so many of our young men go to England to join Regiments aren’t the Australian forces good enough I wonder?
Entry.41:
Big Mail today not yet sorted.

Still marking time & as usual did not get away as soon as expected. Lectured tonight on 
Cosack
 Cossack posts & Outposts as we have many Reinforcements (to 
p
 replace the old men) who have had little practical training but they are all triers

four letters 2/1/16- I did send letter with Paper but no Diary Yes I got Sheepskin from Roger & had him to dinner at Aerodrome.

Just got Australasian of November 20, you see how erratic mails are.

Love to all -Frank
Entry.42:
On Patrol today saw 1 Jackal 1 Gazelle- What they live on I don’t know.

The Jackal dig up the dead natives I think & the Gazelle eat the Camel Bush & Desert Thorn.

We are making a Military Road here to get the Guns out on the Desert, great gangs of Natives & Camels carting Stones, no doubt spys are among them but the English are a trusting lot. 
We now are looking to Roumania for help.
 

Posted
Entry.43:
1.30 A.M. "SAMALUT"

We got a surprise start yesterday morning at 5 A.M. orders came that the Natives had been firing on the Train from 
LUXOR
 so the whole Brigade was ordered to entrain by midday. Here we are now 
South
 of Cairo instead of going North to Mersa Matrue on the Mediteranean I am glad as the Coast air never agrees with me 

X 
The Powers that be never seem to learn much 
X We are carting about great wooden Troughs for Watering the Horses, not collapsible with bands as we use in Australia at the Wells- Then the Head Ropes are always eaten by the Horses- We know that Tarring saves them yet cannot get it for love or money.

"Here endeth the growl."
Entry.44:
BIRTHDAY

We have about a 20 mile front to guard by Patrol & I have spent a very interesting day riding over the Valley of the Nile & along the edge of the Desert- "Omdahs" "Sheiks" ie Native princes & notables met us with great ceremony we rode our horses, then Camels, then in a Hooded buggy drawn by pair of mules imported by a rich Pasha who is apeing Eropeans.

Last night one Pasha invited my Major & myself to a 10 course dinner, soup, lentels Liver & rice, Barley bread, a whole fat tail sheep, Honey, Native Cheese, Cakes, & WHISKEY & Soda-

House lit by Electric Light, we could not speak language but we pantomimed thro’ the feast. The Bedouins use gorgeous saddlery, pink, gold, blue etc colored fringed Saddle cloths & the "Tout ensemble" is imposing- inlaid Pistols & Swords
Entry.45:
I don’t feel any older but another year has gone I hope to be with you all again ere another comes around.

Did I explain that the Brigade is split into Regiments, & the Regiments into Squadrons each unit on its own, then the Squadrons are split again in to troops, & stationed out. You will see by map where Samalut is on the railway. We have a Canal nearby & it is Paradise to the Desert. One feels like a spring heel jack walking on solid ground again after the Desert sand.

An armoured train with search light patrols the railway just like Africa & we patrol the Caravan routes coming in from the Desert-

600 Rifles so far have been collected
Entry.46:
Had a swim in Canals I am getting a bushel of Visiting Cards from the Sheiks & Pashas & enclose some samples-

Just a small pkt of Chewing gum would be acceptable in the heat if we have long days in the Desert in April- On my road today I saw a Traction Engine & 11 furrows Plow on one side & on the other side wooden plow & 2 oxen, the old & the new. I have had the Marmoor or Superintendent & Secretary with me for 2 days, they say they are both sore from riding as our horses are fresh & they are unaccustomed to ride much & generally on Donkeys – & we ate it Bedouin killed a Cock for
Entry.47:
I am having some quaint experiences in the Bedouin Houses, where we patrol & each place kills a Cock & we eat it almost hot, all with our fingers, & seated on the ground.

Our Guide the Marmoor every night says tres fatigue, they are very poor horsemen-

The AMP Society would raise my premium if they knew the filthy cups of coffee we are forced to drink for fear of offending the friendlies.
Entry.48:
Last night fed at Arab house- Fried Catfish, Camel Cheese Maize bread Gramophone played Arabic songs- Pretty girls peeped thro’ 
barred
 doors at us- Tea in glasses filled 3 times- this is the drink & Coffee.

Chance to post so send with love
Entry.49:
Posted yesterday- Today Recd Mothers Joes & Daisys Jan 16. Seidleitz Powders & Soks please thank him- Also letter from Maurie Phillips. Thought old "TESS" would fail some day, a good lucerne paddock is what she wants now. Glad 
German
 measles finish.

Smithy is at 
Helman
 Zeitoun, he wrote me.

Dined with Mohammed 
Pasha
 Abdullah beautiful carpets, China, ( 9 courses,) He owns many wives & much land. Pictures of the Koran worked in silk with immense Gilt frames, also an atrocious silk Cat, done by one of the Harem.

Many Bells, & Mirrors, fans & much finery- but we never mention the wives or even see them
Entry.50:
I frequently knock 2 men riding on 1 donkey I mean natives, They have worked it out to a fine art how much work can be got out of how little feed, very cruel. 
"Starlings"
 are plentiful & I saw an Arab child, with one tied by the leg on a piece of string, as a TOY they are a cruel race- TOY lasted 3 days

Now camped at 
Shusha
 on edge of Desert near 
Samalut
.

Pneumonia Plague is at this village & many deaths- so we hope to move soon We are collecting Rifles like in Africa, & the Mamoor has lent me an old Blunderbuss of shot gun & 
10
 cartridges- so when 5 or 6 Pigeons get a line I pull- not sport but Tucker
Entry.51:
Patrolling

Lunched with Mohammed Pasha, a fine old educated Pasha, who has travelled a lot & been Host to KITCHENER All the Egyptians love "K" Mohammed gave me Brandy 50 years old & a good dinner. He had 2 lovely rings one a Ruby as big as a Rand the other a Signet ring with Antiquity Stone of old Egyptian days handed down from Father to Son- dressed in a Black silk Robe he sat playing with his Amber Beads, like R.C. With my mongrel french we had an enjoyable meal & I am thoroughly enjoying the whole show at present, but not much actual fighting

Recd. Mother’s letter Card looked like 17/12/15- for Birthday
Entry.52:
Patrolling

60% of the children die in the native villages so any that live are mostly immune & can live in the most unsanitary places in the world- great place for sore eyes-"Jupiter"& another star or planet is very bright as the sun goes down- some of the Natives tell us it never was so bright, & must be an English light from Balloon. Shifted to Exbid-SIDHOLM the place of Sef Bays- as Head Quarters thought the risk of plague too great- We commandeered Felucca Boats & floated the Baggage down the 
South
 JOSEPH Canal- Called Joseph’s Canal from time immemorial but spelt in Arabic JOWSEF
Entry.53:
Horses arrived in daylight but the Boats stuck on mudbanks etc & were late- baggage always is. Clearing a place for a camp I unearthed a brown snake- The moon is very full at present & shining on the Canal makes a pretty picture, till broken by a dead donkey etc floating down stream We drink this but boil first with the husks of Corn Cobs if possible- Weather getting warmer now but nights cold-

Invitation for Officers to supper at another Pasha’s tonight so expect a 9 course feed of Lentils, Brains, Viciera etc. Another dog just floated past & Water Buffaloes (domestic) are swimming with a small native child trying to get them out a few hundred yards above Camp
Entry.54:
Well we fed with Pasha taking our revolvers in one Pocket This man is a Copt & on the Walls in Picture frames were Texts in Arabic-

"Do unto others as tho’ you "were going to live 1000 years"

another

"The head of Wisdom is to fear "God" etc & etc:-

Arabic looks like a glorified shorthand commencing on the wrong side of the page ie from right to left-

The War office gives a 50/- BONUS for any soldier who learns to read & write Arabic- I’m not a starter-

These old Pashas & Boys have a lot of native courting /COURTESY & do us well in Coffee & Cigars
Entry.55:
Went 6 miles up stream in a Royal Engineers pontoons tied behind a Felucca- Shot one plover & 2 ducks- floated back with current – took our Doctor & quite enjoyed the day-

Letters from Mother Aunt Louie 
Mrs Cotton & Papers Jany 8 from Mother & of course I always hear from
 Brooklands it is a treat to get news that all’s well & to see an Australasian- 

Mails seem to be better now but the men from ANZAC have so far got no Billies- Thank Mrs Wilkinson for thinking of me but nothing arrived from her.
Entry.56:
Just remembered this was Leap Year, but nothing doing yet- s’pose there will be after WAR 

Court Martial today 2 men got some rotten whisky & threw their Rifle & Clothes into a Canal, practically went Mad-

MUMPS very prevalent in Camp 18 men out of this Squadron alone have gone to Hospital since we left Heliopolis.

 Thank you for Pastoral Times & Australasian- I am afraid there is going to be a bad time ahead for everyone to pay all the Taxation- but it is necessary- better pay up quick, & finish the job then be finished- It’s a like a big drought if we got the Backers & the £, S D we can see it through.
Entry.57:
S S WANDILLA 

No padre with us so no service, lovely weather & nothing doing much. We are camped for some time here we hope & have built a Tucker room or Bough Shed out of maize stalks which grow very rank on the irrigated Nile flats when stiffened with MUD it makes a good cool feeding place.

Flies getting bad again with the warm weather coming on.

You see I am not worrying much about the war, it is each mans daily bread & life he thinks of- we are all really very narrow minded & self satisfied

Todays Patrol was along miles of Cotton crop just irrigated & Beans (Broad beans) quite 2 miles of them- used as cattle feed later on.

We fill our Nosebags after the horses have had their feed

Tried to get a c/- of Johnnie Walker from Cairo, but with so many soldiers about failed again- Stolen- When the war is over some Hero’s !!! will find it hard to be honest again.

Bridge of Pontoons nearly finished across the Canal here so we need no longer share the Punt with Camels Donks, Water Buffaloe & Sore eyed kids.
Entry.58:
I had to go to 
Samalut
 & see the local Magistrate (Egyptian) re some shots fired from a Bedouin Village. 

I found him in the CLUB!!! & was soon surrounded by all the colored Notables & swallowed 2 Whiskies & sodas with great skill-

Thro’ an Interpreter (after much Salaaming etc) I tried to put them right about a few natives ie Maoris do not come from Australia- not any Blackfellows are in our Parliament- etc.

All Classes
 here are much affected by Sedition papers now being circulated, they want to govern themselves they say –

Tried to buy English Paper but only got an Arabic & French one which I send you

Wednesday 1 March 1916

Shot 2 Duck 4 Grouse with 5 cartridges-

Threw stones at Jack Snipe as could not afford to use cartridge only got 10 & cannot buy owing to Martial Law-

Makes ones mouth water to See Quail & Snipe & no Shot cartridges- This on the flooded valley of NILE

Mail in- Letter from May 26/1/16 Annie Mills Laura Mother
Entry.59:
from Katandra Strange Dungalear & of course Mrs D. who enclosed your letter to her she was very nice about it.

Parcel from Ferrar etc all most acceptable received waistcoat from Rev Rogers sometime since- but now of course it is like Nov weather in Australia & thin clothes are the rule.
Entry.60: On Patrol today and by invitation had dinner with another Bedouin Owdah-
Entry.61:
Whole Lamb, head, eye & all & 2 Turkey Cocks- came in- sweets, made of Buffaloe Milk Starch & Sugar,

All eat with hands, & literally tear the food.

The Lambs head was smashed with an axe- & brains Bon Bouche. Our Host could eat a lamb himself he informed me, & I believe it-

Their great ambition is to die knowing that no man has even 
seen
 their wifes. Asking when the Bedouins would rise to help the Desert Arabs, they replied- in Arabic "When two Sundays meet" "God bless you" which of course means never but we pick our man while feeding
Entry.62:
Love to all 

I heard Rogers is al
ways
so a diary keeper – I think I’ll knock off what do you say re -
Entry.63:
Arranged some sports today to celebrate opening of Pontoon Bridge break the monotony for the men Some Copts are building a Church near here altho’ Mohommadens & Copts live together in same villages they would cut each others throat- The Copts show their wrists on which is tattoed a + & reckon we are same sort of Christians as I have some + on my arm where BOILS lanced by Doctors. 

Letter from Joe & Day 23/1/16 & Australasian.

Mits & Soks from Kathleen please thank her-

Also letter from Laura Papers from Mrs Cotton
-

We are glad to get news of the world –You will find me little altered except an extra line or two has been etched on my hard face.
Entry.64:
I got a Teapot from Laura & some Handkies- & more Woollen Soks-

It is quite hot now & about 102° today.

Our horses are doing well but we have trouble to keep them shod, no coal in Egypt & rotten iron in shoes-

No fighting only patrol work but one never knows from day to day what our Desert friends are doing-

If anyone asks you what to send me as per Mrs W- a fountain pen would be most acceptable. Posted notes to Deniliquin yesterday, but am glad you and Day are in Melbourne- Regards to all friends
Entry.65:
We are not supposed to bathe in Canal here or in fact any where in Egypt owing to a hook worm called BILHARDSI entering the System- But I prefer to chance the hook worm to going dirty-

General move on further South to 
Ass but we
 remain where we are 
I am always afraid I say too much in my notes to you, but it would be a conscientious Censor who is able to thro all this.
 I sent you from the Dardanelles an English Army £1note to raffle at ALLIES Day, with ANZAC on it this must have gone done with my other letters & notes in the Trawler
Entry.66:
I had also sent some money to 
Strange
 for Opal but he did not receive it either, I mean at Dungalear. Some awful fake photos are being published 
in Australian papers
 The 
Sun
 16/1/16 has one sent by Capt 
Reynolds
 of A.A. Service Corps shewing 4 wheeled G.S. Wagon & horses & 
Gippies
 loading 
Furniture
!!!! & called the evacuation of ANZAC.

It is so absurd, one wonders at a Paper printing such a thing.

Killed a snake near Tent today, after centipede & Scorpions, but no one seems to get bitten
Entry.67:
This Canal must not be confused with SUEZ

We were startled today by seeing the body of a dead Soldier floating down the Canal- He turned out to be a Queenslander 2nd L.H. drowned 3 days before higher up the Canal.

A sad end for a fighting man – it appears his fell off one of the Ferries & being weighted with Rifle & ammunition had no chance-

We wired for Motor Ambulance & sent him to Minna for decent burial.

Poor old Sef Bey’s brother died last night- much wailing in the village just like our Aboriginals. He was attended by native Doctor who told us this morning "That he died 
accidental
Entry.68:
Went to lunch with another Mahmoud Hossive Pasha usual 9 courses.

He had just returned from Cairo & Tel El Kebir 
Sir John Maxwell
 asked are the Notable Pashas there to visit the Suez Canal & see what measure had been taken by the British to protect Egypt.

This Pasha having seen, said he was now quite satisfied that no enemy could get into Egypt. rather a good move as many of these colored gentry sit on the fence & jump over to safest side.

Have applied for leave to get summer clothing from Cairo but doubt if successful.
Entry.69:
Yesterday met Judge & local prosecutor 
 
 very worthy no doubt but could not understand a word they said, however enjoyed the day.

Just heard my leave granted from tonight till Sunday morning so ride in to 
Samalut
- wired for a bed to Continental Hotel & arrived at 9 pm.

Cairo was a gay city after the Desert, & I intend to combine business with pleasure. 
Rang up Mardi but hear she is out.

Got reserves commissions for A Squadron done & heard all latest news- Not many old friends Cairo is full of Soldiers.

Saturday 11 March 1916

Exchanged 
warm
 Warm clothing for summer things at J Cooks & Son & bought 500 Cartridges for my gun at 
75
 100 P.T. per 100-

Went Heliopolis saw old Camp met Miss Myra Wyse & took her to Tea. 
Mardi Ritchie was out.
 The old Saturday night Dances are on again, at the Principal Hotels but I did not join in. Got some boots & Trousers for the men. Had several Hot baths & took back Mosquitoe Nets for all Officers-

12 March 1916 Sunday 

Caught the 8.30 A M back again- rode out 15 miles to Camp- all the better for my weekend.

Heard that the Infantry 1st & 2nd Divisions are going to France 
do not allow this to be circulated 
 and I think we will be left in Egypt for the summer.

Saw Doly Wilshire in the Distance- but as I was in a train did not stop.

If you do not hear from me for 6 weeks it is because our mail is stopped owing to leakage of information as per above our outgoing English mail is to be stopped also.

Monday 13 March 1916

Paid all hands today:- found great activity among Fellaheins sewing Cotton by hand- many acres adjoining us being good agricultural land. Two Squadrons moved further South near
Assiot
, but we remain in 
Minia
 province. Since Seft Beys funeral
s
 the natives favour us by carrying all their dead past the Camp. While I have been writing 3 funerals have passed. Life is cheap among the Fellaheins- & they settle domestic disputes with a knife or a stick-

Got some MAIL in Cairo & Parcel 
from May, soapenvelopes Soks Handkies
 - 
No more woollen Soks are wanted in Egypt for 6 months too HOT
- Please thank her. (
Print
 large)

Tuesday 14 March 1916

On Patrol I took my gun & shot

3 Widgeon 3 Jack Snipe 4 Quail 3 Plover and 1 snake- With a game of poker or Bridge & a whisky before turning in life is very good at present, & not half as strenuous as it should be of course there are always possibilities of a scrap.

Great gambling going on among the men as there is no way for them to spend their money.

Hear that the German fleet is out

No word of any Xmas Billies for the 1st L H who were at ANZAC the men feel rather disappointed.

Wednesday 15 March 1916

I find the cartridges are all rejects of Clay Bros, all Brands & Powders. Egyptian Storekeepers are Robbers- I had to get a Permit from the Consul to buy them-

Today I shot

10 Jack Snipe

1 Duck

3 Plover

3 Big Brown Doves
Entry.70:
Quail

& nearly drownded a young native getting the Duck. Wish I had my good gun this "made in Germany" is only Goopipe & very old & very cheap.

Just heard the news re ROUMANIA joining in – Good luck to her We will all be home by Xmas- you see
Entry.71:
Paid my condolences to Sef Bey many Native notables come each day to a big Pavilion drink coffee smoke one Cigarette & go away in Silence this is kept up for a fortnight.

Every hour or two great wailing goes on in the House which is given up to the Women.

The men are silent but very impressive & these Arab chiefs are so courteous in their own way- & can teach Europeans a lot in the way of quiet dignity.

Letters today from Mother
Entry.74: Mrs Ainslie Mills Glad to get all news- note old Mrs F.S.F Boonoke died suddenly. Aunt Louie’s letter enclosed in Mother please thank her.
Entry.75:
Went to Dinner again at another Pashas, & found the same round table had been carted per pack Donk from our recent Host. Evidently only the 
only
 one Table in District- Bedouins feed on the floor- & tear the food with hands 

 At one village Collected a 16 bore Shot gun & 20 Cartridges, the latter we were informed were to shoot quail etc: but on opening found they were loaded with Siran drop, the very largest shot made.

Cartridges were filled for man hunting I think.

A bag of newspapers were lost in one of the Canals, Donk fell in- rotten luck, a man has a lot of luck to get his mail at this game & when it does arrive he appreciates it.
Entry.76:
Life jogs on here much as usual chased 4 Camels today, but they went West, double outposts tonight, but many Tourists would pay good money to lead the life we are doing. Spent the evening Condoling with Sef Bey conversation as follows- 

"We hope you are getting over your"

" trouble" (all thro’ Interpreter)

"Your visits make my burden light, it is the will of God"

We hope our men are behaving themselves in the villages & on patrol,

All the Notables of the Province speak highly of yourselves & your soldiers & children remember them in their prayers

etc, etc:

 Throw bouquets at each other & then more coffee & a cigarette & we leave
Entry.77:
Today I went to a Coptic Church Service, 
really R.C.
 The Priest wore a Silver Brocade!!! gown with Gold Tinsel (Poppy Pattern) & a Cowl or hood of same—Choir of boys, Incense was burnt & many candles Music consisted of Cymbals & Triangles. The boys mostly X eyed wore Red Plush Caps & had good voices- all Arabic. All the (Bints) girls & women were in a Gallery with screen to hide them Most gaudily painted with Doves etc & glass Candleabra on which the sparrows perched.

Sing Song service, they never punctuate like in conversation only stop to take breath, & stare at us. Towards the end, an interpreter butted in with enclosed translation in bad English & I had to thank them Communion was held 
& I brought 1 cake home
.

After Service the priest fed us on Quail Pigeon, Whisky Soda etc so we go next Sunday.
Entry.78:
Today shot 3 ducks 7 Quail 4 Curlew 4 Jack snipe 3 Plover & some sort of Grouse. The line of demarcation between Desert & Valley of the Nile is like a fence, 20 yards between the two. Out on the Desert, not even a bird is seen, only Lizards

Inspected & took photo of Native Incubator- 1000’s of eggs, & chicks falling out of them & in adjoining mud hut the Chicks were fed leaf kept up by Maize stalks I told you before 
Hens
 never sit in Egypt.

Now on last night in adjoining village Natives killed, 20 wounded. Weapons used- old guns, reaping hooks, etc :- & row over a piece of land, we had to turn out but only a local disturbance. 

Letter from Mardi inclosing one from Kathleen & one from you ex Katandra, glad to hear all’s well
Entry.79:
10 Quail 4 Ducks 4Jack Snipe 1 Painted Snipe 3 Plover for dinner tonight.

Poor starved soldier!!! But tomorrow comes & we know not & most of us have had a past too.
Entry.80:
Well here I am 300 miles South of Cairo at 
Soh Sohag
 I did not think the shooting would last- all too good- Got a wire by Helio at 11.30 at night to entrain next morning, for Brigade Head Quarters.

I am to be Staff Captain (ie red tab) Officers I have always criticized & now am to be one of them & today am miles away picking the Camp- I write this in a Palm Grove.

Past miles of Cotton Lentils, Beans, Barley Sugar Cane, fancy 100s of miles of intense cultivation.

Sorry to leave the 1st Reg: but of course they are one of the Regiments of Brigade- address as of old.
Entry.81:
Of course it is promotion but it means leaving all the officers & men I have worked with & I live now with General 
Cox
.

Plenty to do & no doubt I shall get well cursed.
Entry.82:
Posted Diary hope you could read it- fear I cut leaves too close.

I am very busy so forgive much my job is generally carrying out the General’s wishes, when things go wrong so one long growl, anyone in the Army will tell you what a Staff job means- 
but
 

 I’m in bed every night, large Tent & many luxuries so if my health which is good, stands I shall be alright.

I refuse to be worried about anything, but will do my damndest, & angels can do no more,In many ways I’d sooner be in the Trenches but had we stayed at ANZAC I am sure I never would have stood the cold.
Entry.83:
Hotter here I rode 30 miles South to find another suitable camp site today, all the Nile Valley is much the same 100’s of miles of good land about 6 miles wide only with Desert on each side. 

The Highland Mounted Brigade are with us, their officers eyed me closely to see if I had the Regular Officers who have knocked about the world treat us well, but some of the hide bound, jumped up Temporary Officers put on a lot of dog & speak of the Beastly Colonials it is a pity- as a wrong impression is formed on both sides.
Entry.84:
No church parade too hot.

Letters will go astray here for a while I expect, but I telegraphed for mine.

I have much Office work at present, and a rotten Bronchial cough.

The old 1st L.H. Brigade is very different to what it was, so many changes a man is almost a stranger & naturally one misses the old faces.

It is nice to hear the Squirl of the Bagpipes again at the Highland Mtd Brigade. Bands etc have been cut out of our life for many months now.

The best I ever heard was when we were played to our Camp on Lemnos Island, after the last night on the Peninsular.

Monday’ 27 March 1916 

Sent a Requisition to Ordnance for 520 Helmets assorted sizes got answer back today are these GAS!!!!

Fancy any man in Ordnance thinking Gas Helmets were wanted in Egypt; these are the sort of delays & replies of Red tape unthinking officials.

Received letters from

 Grace Galbraith 14/2/16 Walter Campbell
Entry.85:
& Joh

Those I wrote to the base for yours will be coming along.

Very hot

All my photos of Native destroyed by Native photographed,I felt inclined to pitch him into the Nile, only reply I could get was "it is the will of ALLAH"
Entry.86:
Appointed Camp Commandant for 2 Brigades while here. Only an attached job, but still promotion without any extra emoluments. 

 Sandflies, Mosquitoes & Flies bad- 
Hot as Hell
 Am offered a 
room
 with a 
Bathroom
 in the town of 
Sohag
 & Mess with the Officers of the Hd Quarters of Highland Mounted Brigade, don’t know yet whether I’ll take it on or not, as prefer to Mess 
with the old Brigade Officers
 

These English chaps are so suspicious & never let themselves go, of course there is no doubt a lot of our chaps are scrubbies, but a lot of their Officers are snobs.
 

Cold much better.
Entry.87:
Luxurious Bathroom & cool Bedroom.

My duty work seems to try & settle claims for damage to crops, by Camps etc:- 

Using the water pumped at the Railways & Town Council & all the questions of a Town Council, Sanitation, Bounds Town Police etc:-

How long will all this last!

I forcaste a change back up North again 
very
 soon.

Senussi are funished I think. Gyppies are rogues if the British paid nothing, it would serve them right, they claim for all sorts of imaginary things & lie thro’ a 10" board.
Entry.88:
Today I had some business with the Principal of Technical College- There are 14 of these & include all Trades- & Agriculture. The Native students are making me a pair of boots for 80 P.T. & presented me with a hand worked silk handkerchief.

Slept last night in a double Bed - sheets- Cold shower-etc etc.

Recd letters from Laura Mch 1 Joh:-

Heavy Khamsin or Dust Storm & 
very hot

On Court Martial of SIKH Indian Mountain Battery who shot his Sgt Major pure Murder.
Entry.89:
Scotchmen treat me very well & I’m quite happy in my new job. Cold better, & plenty of work.

Near here are antiquities & Tombs with the bones of many past generations I have not had time to explore yet.

I am posting you some Negatives, which you have printed if you like, but P.O.P has become so dear & scarce in Egypt that I send you the Films only I have labeled the Films what they represent.

Many good Films are spoilt by the Native photographers as Developing Mixtures are almost unobtainable in Egypt.
Entry.90:
Sports on at Highland Mounted Brigade & I got some snapshots of the Scotchmen wrestling on Donkeys & a Camel Race. 

 Letter from Nowell Forth today, from Sudan. 

 We sent out Aeroplanes reconnaissance & dropped Bombs on some 200 

Senussi at 
Kharga Oasis
 but the weather has been against Flying. 

 If you look at map of Nile you will see 
Sohag
 is a long way South All sorts of rumours about returning North again soon but nothing definite.
Entry.91:
Inspected a Camp 13 miles South – The only trouble appeared to be the number of Scorpions- in the old mud walls around the Camp Expect to be going North soon We have all had enough of Upper Egypt.

The natives do not like us down here- more Mohammedans & Copts.
 Owing to the teaching of Australian one Copt in all innocence today approached me to sell fruit in Camp- Baring his Arm he showed me the Coptic + & said "I’m a b--- Christian".
Entry.92:
Sgt WEIR a namesake died today of TYPHUS & PNEUMONIA a good fellow who did good work on the Peninsular.

Photos prints are an exorbitant price in this part of EGYPT 5 PT = 1/- for each print so I send you Films only.

One aeroplane was fired at this morning & two bullets put through the Wings but the Senussi are not in any strength & have mostly gone 
Tripoli
 way.

Met Captain Arnold a Doctor brother to Ralph Arnold the latter also has a Commission now in an Infantry Battalion.

I suppose Lorna knows this. When is Charlie’s 21st Birthday sometime in April?
Entry.93:
Sandflies have bitten one Scotch Officer so badly he has gone to Hospital.

Camels even are feeling the heat now poor brutes get hell- if they lag behind, the natives pull out a knife & cut a hole in 
their nostril
 Camels Nose & tie a piece of leather or hide on & drag ‘em along.
Entry.94:
150 miles from here there is an Oasis with old Roman Wells- timbered for about 50 feet & then bored & cased with wooden pipes the wood is still quite sound a sort of Sycamore- 600 B.C. As very little timber is now growing in this part of Egypt these Wells must be 1000’s of years old. Artesian & warm.

Visited an old Monastry 1600 years old occupied by Copts who had to build strong holds to save themselves from the Mohammedans.

So very old & so very dirty no wonder the Children died.

VERDUN seems to be the place of affairs at present We only get what news is good for us
Entry.95:
Too much whisky is drunk here altogether-(Our Staff are not in the same ratio as our men, & many incapables are working with good men but who drink more than is good for them.)

Over the Desert today to some Tombs were mummies of men or children, were there for the taking, wrapped up in the LINEN made 2000 B.C, even the hair was good & the teeth perfect-!!!

I’m not keen on but the paintings on the roofs of the Tombs 
we
 are wonderfully fresh & the colors better than any pigments of today- (
The mummies are there for the taking.
Entry.96:
(Big mail tonight Mother Joe Daisy Jean Mathis Miss Chase Cuthbert Fetherstonehough May Harrison & Papers from Joe- Cannot answer all.)

I see my missing Diary is one containing £1 in Gallipoli Notes, also a sketch I made of our position & some of my letters must be in Davy Jones locker. Still I’m not, so that’s all right.

Went to see some Howling Dervishes dance tonight mostly naked 
men
 & Tom Toms & Backsheesh 

Senussi chucking it, & we are to occupy Kharga Oasis, West of Oasis Junction. see map
Entry.97:
Bought a pair of Boots made by Natives at Technical School for 80 P.T.

Much excitement this morning our 2 Aeroplanes landed close to our Camp been out reconnoitring, they have done the Cavalry out of a job, being able to go many miles out on the Desert.

The Natives swarm around in front, behind simply no use hitting them out of the way. When propeller goes, they shift. 

Impossible to answer all letters, but they are much appreciated.

(Can’t say I remember Pvt Street, but I know he was one of the old crowd.)
Entry.98:
Am fast forgetting all about the Peninsular as I have forgotten Elands River & past droughts. What a happy thing it is we can do so.

Severe Khamsin or Monsoon, Dust storm, like a good Riverina Dust storm. Enclose more snaps of Nile etc. (I am not likely to forget you Mother.)

I have come to the conclusion the Egyptians are SNOBS, when introducing anyone the formula is "He is a very rich man" or "I am the son of a BEY or PASHA" - & they are always keen to know one’s rank etc etc:- the result of years of slavery to the Turks I suppose.

Posted Joe a Tarbush or Fez tonight’s mail hope he gets it.
Entry.99:
Sergeant Weir is buried near the Monastery I spoke of visiting a few days ago. The Coptic Priest was anxious he should be buried very close to the walls of the Monastery "Have then a better chance "of resurrection" & more pay to the Priest- The nearer the Monastery the dearer the grave from 4d to 6d according to distance.

However we have now a portion of ground set apart for the Soldiers & are erecting a nice Memorial Stone for the poor chaps I remember one grave at ANZAC on which was written in indelible Pencil on Wooden cross the two words CARRY ON.

Tuesday 11 April 1916

Word has just come in that our Armoured Cars out Baharia Oasia way made a smart capture- of a Turkish Officer & his 3 Bedouin Guards. This Turk had crossed Arabia 
Araba
 then the Red Sea about the middle thence via Luxor to the rail-way & out to Fayoum –Osais. They made their Camels kneel & got behind them to fire bur eventually on seeing 2nd Car arrive, surrendered.

I cleaned up that locket you gave me & which I wear as an identity Disc, & did wear all thro’ Africa, it should be a good mascot to bring me home once more, I am afraid we are all getting a bit homesick now. Col Meredith o/c
Entry.100: L.H. here tonight, wants me back but I’m quite happy here.
Entry.101:
Thousands of Armenians are in this country, the Turks have murdered about one million already & Poor devils they are very destitute & their future a blank- we have one as Cooks offsider for the Mess.

Today a race between a Camel & a troop horse over 6 miles, I’m backing the Camel.

Later
 The horse won, to our surprise the Camel could not last.

Prince of Wales went thro’ in train tonight from Luxor, all Egyptian Notables crowded the train to see him, his rank is Staff Captain, & keep out of the road. (please thank May many thanks for MITS.) omit
Entry.102:
Today a long string of Camels & the Highland Mt. Brigade with Hong Kong Mt. Battery go to Kharga Oasis, we are in support.

(By tonight’s Cables I see Capt C.D. Tyson Royal Artillery is wounded in France & I’m wondering if it is young Charlie. He may have been tempy Capt: but I hope it’s not true) omit

Severe "Khamsin" Dust Storm today, dined with Fife, Yeomanry & had a HAGGIS, a real one & I’m not keen on ‘em- in the heat.

Back to Brigade Hd Qrts today as one Brigade has gone & I’m sent to Minia to enquire into misdeeds of 2 N.C.O’s up there.

I Received letter from May 5/3/16 SOKS & stamps (we don’t use) & Mits from Mother & Boracic Acid & CHOCOLATE " May
Entry.103:
Messed with the ROYAL NORTH DEVON HUSSARS & by chance a Capt asked me if I knew Capt Charlie Brace late of Australia Artillery, who married a rich Australian an awful bounder. I let him run on & then said Yes he married my sister! Capts name Capt Ruston

The recent 
Camps
 Duststorm is over, the Natives say it blows away the Plague & fertilises the Date Palms by scattering the Pollen, which has to be artificially done if Palms grow far apart as you know the Palms are of two sexes- & if not growing in thick clumps they do not bear much fruit unless artificially. the Pollen is spread from Tree to Tree.
Entry.104:
Returned Minia ordered a steak, Green Peas, Chip Potatoes & Tea at Restaurant-(YAK steak) Another name for the Water Buffaloe or local cow Owner said You Australians always order the same so housewives can note!!!

(Dr Arnold has married a Nurse out here don’t know her. I told you Ralph has a Commission.) omit 

 I s’pose a man will be able to earn some daily bread when this is all over, all I want is clean shirts, clean linen, plenty of flowers & no flies, that’s how I feel tonight; as I’m back under Canvas, & the dust is very bad, whenever the horses go to water, it fills the ears, eyes, nostrils, tucker blankets & everything. Still better than Blizzards
Entry.105:
Not a bad name for Egypt land of PALMS.

One of the Highland Staff gave me 2 books as he is off to England. One is "The first 100 000" 
KI
 a War yarn top hole- & the other a dear Irish story called "old Andy, which the poor old Pater would have loved to have read to him, read them just like old Donoughmore.

("Old Andy" is by Dorothea Conyers Received letter from Joe 5/3/16, from & Kath 6/3/16 please thank them.) omit

Inoculated for PARO-TYPHOID again today- expect to feel a bit off tomorrow but Typhoid bad down this way.
Entry.106:
Palm Sunday was really kept up here & the Copts decorated their Church. I watched a Native putting the Pollen from one tree to another, first sprinkling the flowers of the female tree with Sugar cane juice, which he chewed & spat out, so that the other pollen will stick on.

On enquiry I hear that it is 7 years before the Female flowers, & 2 years before the Male does, only the former bears dates, but the sex may change in a few rare occassions.

Male tree has smaller thorns & harder & blossoms before the Female as a rule.

The dates are sown in the fibre of another tree 6" in the ground about 100 stones to the square foot & when they come up the male seedlings are straight & strong the females weaker & bent- the proportion about 2 of the later to 1 of former as the Males do not bear only a few trees are transplanted

(I feel a bit sick from Virus)
Entry.107:
Under separate cover sending you some snap shots & a Palm Cross, given me by an Arab Child last Sunday.

Lovely moonlight nights & no ill effects except temporary usual 
over
 from inoculation

I’ve been punctured so often now I must be full of alien Bacillus but sickness is very prevalent here

(Love to all & hope these notes reach you all at home safely) omit

I see Parson Rogers is also writing his impressions, wonder 
you
 the paper does not get tired of printing Soldiers letters etc. think I’ll knock off if we don’t get some fighting soon, but its for you Mother dear I do it, as you see my daily life.
Entry.108:
Went Assuit on Court Martial of a SIKH Gunner who shot his Sgt Major dead . MURDER charge.

Feel a but off color from inoculation.

There’s a large Barrage or Dam here across the Nile & it is quite a nice place after Sohag. Passed a lot of Poppy Fields these are sold straight from the fields to the Native Women, who use, steeped in Water & as an anaesthetic Not much "opium" is made locally- some Poppies exported. One of the 5th Army Service Corps (Australian), gone to hospital today with Small Pox and another Queenslander with Plague.
Entry.109:
Sitting on Court Martial Assuit this is a nice town & Capital of 
Upper
 Upper Egypt.

The Sikh is a hard man to get evidence out of & we will be 
hear
 here for some days as all evidence has to be taken through an Interpreter & dragged out of ARAB witnesses also. These are fine looking men & it will be pity to have to Condemn to death such soldiers.

We have the use of the main Court House & the seats etc. are crowded with Curious Egyptians come to see this trial by the British, altho’ few can understand what is being said. they seem to take great Interest. 110° today.
Entry.110: Court Adjourned- Mosquitoes bad very hot- I am to report to Divisional Head Quarters near Ismailia as soon as Court Martial is over, on Staff job up there for about a month- hope to be in Cairo, but must return to Sohag for my horses & kit, but one never knows now I am on Staff job when it will end.
Entry.111:
22- Assuit- Adjourned Court for Easter Am living in comfort now. We have a true saying "No lice, no Typhus No fleas no Plague," as these animals are the carriers- Armoured Train is stationed here, the same sort we used in Africa

Easter Day
Entry.112:
CAIRO

Rused
 Rushed up here from Assuit got some clothes; leave again 11 o’clock Express Sitting in train was a man I last met in Portugese East Africa at 
Beira
 BEIRA.

Had only a few hours to get a few nessesaries and in my hurry left Watch in lavatory-

You’ll think I’m losing my head, Belt at Lemnos & now Watch here.

I may get watch but the Native servants steal anything 
of
 from "
FOOL SAHIBS
"
Entry.113:
Court all day today as 
all evidence 
 Evidence is given through an Interpreter HINDUSTANI & again sometimes in ARABIC with the Native witnesses it is a long tedious case.

Did I tell you it was a case of a Sikh soldier murdering his Native Officer shot him in the night while asleep but evidence is difficult to get, & the Witnesses swear Black is White & vice versa.

(Hear that Myra Wyse has gone to Marseilles) omit
Entry.114:
Court again today & in the evening I dined with Sami Famous & Zaki Bey, in one of the most gorgeous Homes I have seen. A splendid dinner well served nice linen silver & glass, the latter man was educated at Oxford & is quite accomplished - & very rich.

Received Mail- Mother

 -Australian from Joe

 - Daisy 12/3/

 -Laura

 -May 19/3/16

Please tell latter I got her Sox etc & also Lornas I cannot write to everyone much as I should like to answer.

Sorry some of my notes are again missing omit
Entry.115:
Court again all day I’m doing all the writing & have no time to write a word to you & it is an awful scribble sometimes my fountain pen’s good more often damnable. Word has come we have had a reverse on the Canal a matter of Outposts only, but its bad news- & I would be with the Division now, if not on this Court martial, but this is good experience. I have written 148 pages of evidence so far.

Very hot & court crowded with unwashed Natives. The INDIAN SIKHS are fine clean good looking Soldiers.
Entry.116:
Court again We work 8 ½ hours daily in the heat in Court .

Have just heard about the men rioting in Sydney & Liverpool if those are the sort of men who are coming over, We would be better without them, it needs a strong man & a good man to handle a crowd 
like
 that but what a start for a young soldier, it is almost unbelievable.

The Copts here held a Bazaar for the British + & made about 800/-/-. I am keeping a little Water Color of a Sheik for you Mother. 
Do you ever do any painting now, am so glad to hear you can walk so much better.

Khamsin or Sirocco tonight all Dust .

Friday 28 April 1916

Court again. From 9.AM to 6pm. it drags on, wasting time. We have 3 Barristers among the Officers sitting 2 Scotchmen 1 Englishman & they are having the time of their lives quite enjoying it all. I am quite satisfied as to the lying powers of both Sikh & Fellaheen.

Further Mail today Mother 3/3/16 Mrs Strange Day 3/3/16 Laura
Entry.117: & of course ISH & Punches from Mr Ferrer- From the letters arrived a week later
Entry.118:
Court again. These Sikhs have a conspiracy of Silence, & it is a slow biz dragging out evidence. I rewrite all the evidence every night 2 hours work.

I found tonight what can be found in many wealthy Eastern houses- An old English Governess who had been for
Entry.119:
years in Egypt She told many things about the rotteness of the Rich Pasha’s homes, & the way in which they endeavoured to Copy the English being the sincerest form of Flattery.

Truth, Honesty-Morality are sadly lacking in Egypt & they are quite unfitted to govern themselves.
Entry.120:
Went to 3 Churches, the Coptic, Armenian & Missionary & the Arabic Christians, the middle one made the most noise & I should think was furthest away. the first, burnt incense & Candles etc:- the latter the dirtiest- truly there are many ways to Heaven & only one God.

Got a wire asking how long I shall be here on the Trial as I’m wanted on the Canal, where there is trouble again & our whole 1st L.H. Brigade are to join again with the ANZAC Light Horse Division. composed of Australian & N Zealands
Entry.121:
Court again. Hear that the 2nd L.H. Brigade are fighting on the Canal, I would have been in this but for the Trial Hear that Brigadier Ryan is shot through the stomach & another 124 other Casualties. 

Glad to hear young Charlie got off with a slight wound.

Mosquitoes bad-

My horses are in good order the Gov. are supposed to Clip; Shoe; etc, but I find it costs a lot the upkeep in these small ways. when away from the Regiment.
Entry.122:
Court again 
We hear of poor old Ireland’s revolution! What does it all mean? & soldiers doing the same in NSW on a small scale will add to the propaganda of the Germans- It is hard to believe-

You know the song:- 

"When Irish eyes are smiling" is very popular among the troops.

We sat 8 hours & 20 minutes in court yesterday. & I’ve written 240 pages of Foolscap-

Took photo of Barrage & Lock, this is what is wanted on the 
W
 Darling & Murrumbidgee Rivers.
Entry.123:
Court again. We start on another Case today I cant tell you verdict of 1st one until it has been confirmed. Hope to see Nowel tomorrow

This Court Martial has been a complete change to the Desert & Patrols & a treat to get away from the Dust & Flies-

There is no use any lady coming to the front unless in really good health, they only go sick and then it takes 2 sound men to look after them

I am glad Harry has gone back he was quite .
Entry.124:
Court again. Finished CM at noon & came Cairo with Judge Advocate worked it well to see Nowell & stay 2 days, till Court is Dissolved-

Nowell is thin but well has 3 months Holiday & goes to England lucky beggar he is a Colonel very like his old Father & a great row of Ribbons for Gippy decorations.

He wishes to be remembered to you all-

I have taken a couple of Photos which I will send you-

We have had a great yarn, but he tires easily-
Entry.125:
Busy shopping & going to teeth attended to, these notes please are not interesting-

Hear our men are doing well in France- a Mail is in but all my letters will be with the Brigade Will have time to write you decently & also Mrs Forth. Nowell has quite "Le Grande manner" & has the slow (plenty of time) manner of those who live in the East for long- We bridged a few years in yarning from old Carrakoorte days-

Saw Cuth Fetherstonhough & his wife both well.
Entry.126:
Got some Decent Uniforms again & the Head Waiters will not now put me where I cannot hear the Band or give many Flowers on the TABLE, as appearances go a long way with this type of man both in Egypt as in any other place.

(Nowell I thought would have gone to Australia but he says like everyone & everything else it is après la guerre.) omit

Met a sgt of the old Bushman a man called Keenan, who has come over to Cairo to open a branch of the 
G
 Commonwealth Bank in Cairo.
Entry.128: Went Kantara between Port Said & Ismailia, just read an order that "no meat put up in tins by Davies Toronto, should be eaten as fish hooks have been mixed up by enemy in USA. Turks aeroplane brought down at Port Said this morning.
Entry.129:
re Rail warrant 54143

Had a swim in the Canal yesterday I mean the SUEZ not the dirty freshwater Nile Canals that we have lived on in Upper Egypt for so long.

Great Ships passed but no one takes any notice of the brown naked soldiers & it keeps them so fit.

Court Dissolved & I’m waiting Cairo for my Horses & Batman before going Kantara, you will see it on the Canal, north of Ismalia. Our Camp is 20 mile to the East on a 
PIPELINE
 Military Railway which is being extended daily
Entry.130:
Still Cairo & enjoying every hour of it, Plenty to do fixing up affairs for the Regiment Very Hot.

Met an old Bushman Sgt who has come over to open a Branch of the Commonwealth Bank- 

but too late as I hope in 2 months we will be in France or England (Private)

Horses, Kit, & men arrive 9 pm & I leave at 7 AM in the morning

DIVISIONAL C.O. Gen CHAUVEL

BRIGADE C.O. Gen COX

Reg C.O. Col MEREDITH
Entry.131:
personal Kantara on Suez Canal

Big Mail here waiting for me Mother Mch 19 Mch
Entry.132:
enclosure Daisy Mch 25 Independent Joe. Mch 19th & gumleaf Mrs Cotton April 17th Mrs Mack Mch 28th 

ISH. Glad to hear etc: Alls Well

Laura April 12

Norman Turner re Sheep Skins 

Note Day is sending me 2 Skins- many thanks but do not spend your £ S.D.

Glad Joe met Stead I very seldom get the Papers.

Am glad the old Paters grave is kept so green

Soks & Handky from Maurie Phillips please thank.

Friday 12 May 1916

40
 20 miles East of Kantara.

Very Hot & camped on the desert where the Yeomanry were cut up recently-

Flies bad, but after my spell at Court Martial & Cairo I am quite satisfied to buck in assistant DAQME if you know what that is- A at Divisional H.Q. Deputy Assistant Quarter Master General- Temporarily Sounds important ??

Search lights from ships passing along Suez Canal beam across the Desert & a Military Train carries a search light also.

Nothing but Sand dunes & desolation, no cultivation no Egyptians only Arabs
Entry.133:
Photos

Return to Reg today to Hill 70 (hills only in name, really sand dunes.

 

Lost my job for a time owing to row with a Yeomanry Brigade Major, tell you all about it someday

I said-"The Yeomanry were caught napping" he reported me to Army Head Quarters & General Chauvel sent me back for a while, anyway, as he could do nothing else am afraid I often say too much in these notes.

Our Brigade just marched past so covered with dust they were hardly recognizable. No Tents tonight under the stars again.
Entry.134:
1st L.H. Arrive 10 AM

Busy fixing up Camp once more 120 in SHADE inside a Tent last week- but better than the cold.

We can carry very little kit & it pays to have a few articles of the 
very best
 quality only- the good PANTS. 

 My only regret is that I did not punch the Yeomanry Officers head. They are mostly blue blooded Lords. No mails are to go to England or Australia for a fortnight

Saw young Allanson today- & many men that I have not seen for a long time.

Captain of the day today.
Entry.135:
C.O. made me Mess Secretary to start a Regimental mess again as we have been separated so long in Squadrons Very hot & a man has no comforts on the Desert, the Flies are in myriads 
We have an artillery road & a light military railway
 Turkish aeroplanes come & have a look at us, but keep their Bombs for shipping & bigger game. Cuth Fetherstonhough passed in the Trucks today 
they
 the 12:L.H. are now camped within a mile of us. 

I see my 
Permanent
 rank of Captain only went thro’ in orders dated April 13th as no vacancy in Brigade occurred before- but I have been a Temporary Captain for 7 months
Entry.136: A cool night bucks one up for the following day. Only 2 drinks per day for the Horses & 1 gallon per man every drop of water is pumped along a small pipe from Barges on the Canal. In the Australasian April 1, there are illustrations of plenty of young men at social functions & Button Days etc Pity the don’t exchange their Garden Parties for the Desert & Flies All our Water for drinking is carried in flat sided Galvanised ironed Tins called Fantassies. You can imagine how hot they get on the Camels, by midday.
Entry.137:
Signaller shot today Scattered Turks all around- 120° in the shade 1 gallon Water per man-

160 Camels arrived to take us on

No more roads

No more Railway

No more Pipe Line

Only wells & brackish water

60 men Sunstroke

20 more sick 

survival of the fittest now, I prefer the heat but I like water. The unfit will go to the Wall out here- 2 Camels & 3 horses died -coming out
Entry.138:
Marched out at 3.30 AM a long dusty line of Camels & men. Expect a scrap at any time Passed some dead Turks it is hard to bury a man properly as they swell up & the sand is so loose they come to the surface not to mention the Jackals. On outpost all night beautiful night, only thing that is beautiful is the stars Country just like the Sand Hummocks at Warrnambool .

Stand to arouses everyone @ 3.
45
 AM till 5 AM
Entry.139:
Marched out at 3.30 AM & saw a sight I have not seen since Elands River fight- rows & rows of dead horses & Camels –graves of Turks & Yeomanry- at 
Quatia
 Camp equipment & love letters

Captured 12 sheep & 8 Bedouins but noTurks.

Everything left in the Yeomans Camps- Blankets Helmets & 
Polo Balls
!! 
Golf sticks!!
 great Tables & ovens & Whiskey & Champagne bottles & we poor devils can hardly get drinking water carried it is not to the Credit of the Regiment. I have 
NOT
 mentioned 12 Hours in the saddle, could hear Warships bombarding further up the Coast but I must be careful what I write.

Some of the Photos & letters were disgustingly indecent.

Saturday 20 May 1916

Ere this reaches you no harm done – as Mails will be scarce. If a man is wounded here he is put in a Cacholet sort of cradle & put on a Camel. Some of our men carried a fly blown wounded Yeoman 7 miles over the sand he was so thankful & 

so scornful of his own crowd for having left him.

My "Papers" re my remarks have come back from the G.O.C. with a minute on them for me to NOTE- However I’m quite happy to be back with the Regiment 
 

Big guns firing in the Distance today I think from the Warships.

Sunday 21 May 1916

That Bob Ronald of the 6th Light Horse (from Nap Nap) he is well but like everyone else looks a lot older-

6 Bags of mail at B.H.Q. so hope for News.

We are working along the road Napoleon took in his great March to Egypt & back- All soakage Wells & brackish at that, but we are doing proper Light Horse work – at last. Picked up a fine Bomb dropped by our own aeroplanes it had not burst so we buried it carefully & well in the sand.

Church Parade today.

The Bomb was supposed to have been dropped on the Turks they retired from Canal

Monday.22 May 1916

 

Letter from you & enclosure from Dorothy Hungerford- thank you Mother also big box of Cigarettes I think from Harry Austin please ask him if he sent. I will write him myself but never know our luck think they must be from him.

Just found a note the Cigarettes were from Albert Tyson??!! Very good of him.

I will not risk posting this Diary till I get nearer Civilization or the chance of getting through are small per Camels etc: & Censors are strict.

Thank you for Printed notes they refresh my memory of where we were.
Entry.140:
If the a/c in the Daily Mirror of the recent 
Quatia
 fight here is a sample of information given to the Public, I wonder what the true position is at Verdun? Because it is most misleading 

 Aeroplanes fly every morning over our Camp so low they frighten the Horses- A message is dropped & then away they fly again.

It must be hard to discern everything from above & the day of the Light Horseman is not yet over as a scout.

The Star of Bethlehem shines very brightly at night, but I wish MOSES had made his Water Improvements a little more permanent. The nights are cool & beautifully starlit, but midday hot, 
& sweaty
 we get a cool breeze from the Mediteranean

 

Wednesday 24 May 1916 

Empire Day

Our Patrol were in touch with the Tank Patrols today & exchanged a few shots

The N.Zealanders lost a Pack Horse.

All hands hope for a good scrap soon to balance a/c for the Yeomanry losses. 
The more one sees of the latter smash, the less palatable it appears.

Boils again on the arms.

You might post me a Packet of Mighty Coal Tar soap, it lathers in the Brackish Water. We sleep in our Boots & Clothes every night but nobody minds as we are on the "job" again now.

Thursday 25 May 1916

 Took 6 Camels to Yeomanry Camp & brought back some useful equiptment etc.

Took photos for O.C. Camel Corps of dead Horses Camels etc have left my own camera in Egypt but may get some prints.

Topped up a few graves. I wonder will the Capitalists in Australia still want married Couples for Boundary Riders 
without
 encumbrances !! after this war. One station bred boy is worth two immigrants any day, both in Australia & here. Come here & see! Poor Mother I’m not running down the English & believe in the Crimson thread of Kinship but not Polo, Bedrooms, Baths etc in the Desert. 

Friday 26 May 1916

Hotter again &
Boils again as well as
 flies are an awful curse.

Bob Ronald of Nap Nap from the 6th L.H. came to my Tent & had a yarn.

And many other L.H. men of the 2nd Brigade- The rest of the 1st L.H. Brigade arrived today – 2 LH & 3 L.H. The Ambulance have made a sort of Sleigh out of a Sheet of Galvanised Corrugated Iron pulled along the sand by a Camel & Chains, to collect sick men in- & wounded.

Found 6 Tents buried in the sand near the Yeomanry Camp evidently by Bedouins

Saturday 27 May 1916

Recd 2 Australasian April 1st & 8th thanks.

Some of the Regiment went to the Sea for a swim I have not been yet. Very little news reaches us here of what is going on in the world & Censorship is stricter than ever. Been busy making a place for Aeroplanes to land.

The Heat is quite moist so different to the dry Upper Egypt heat & consequently the Flies are worse & especially the larger varieties the same Green Bronze Fly that causes so much damage to sheep, is plentiful here.

Sandflies bad.

Laura never mentioned a word about Charlie’s
Entry.142:
Letter found these come by degrees from Divisional Hd Qts- Sunday

I have some unexploded Aeroplane Bombs & Turkish Field Artillery shells, but cannot carry along. Curios lose interest when a man is hungry.

I send the notes on to ISH in England she likes to have them after you send them to me.

Sticky clothes again like the Salt Water washing on the Peninsular
Entry.143:
We are doing a lot of night Patrolling now, the Turks follow us back & signal with Electric torches but you may hear of us doing something worth while shortly, a 3 days Stunt. Camels carry our Water, they are absolutely silent at night, great gaunt animals they look very weird & all that can be heard is the swish of the Water in the Fantassies Copper or Iron Water Tanks- holding 15 gallons each, 2 to a Camel- on each side of Pack.

Move out at 10 pm for ---------

Big case of Mufflers Mits, Balaclavas etc arrived for men, such a waste at this time of the Year
Entry.144:
120° yesterday

The men frequently find old Roman Coins along the Beach Track, evidently from the Monastery which is built close to Mohamediy shown on the map- on the Coast near the Cygoon I have not been to the sea yet-

Rode all last night & got into Camp at 5 AM New Zealanders are ahead of us.

We are Camped at --------- (Ognatina) where some more Yeomanry were cut up- but they fought well judging by the heaps of empty Cartridge cases- & many dead. We found one poor horse still alive, doing a perish for Water

.
Entry.145:
If anything happens to me don’t forget to write to T. Cook & Son Cairo – Manager Anglo Egyptian Bank Cairo-

Passed many dead at -------- (Ognatina ) our last reinforcements were most interested & no doubt some journalist would be able to give a good description of the battle field.

The Turks had taken all the good Boots & Water bottles & left theirs, the latter were branded "BERLIN 1914 

Like the other Yeomanry Camps there was signs of a luxurious life & what beat me was a 2 Seater Bob Sleigh like the Canadian or Switzerland ones evidently carted out for Amusement to Toboggan down the Sand dunes!!! but this may not be fair criticism!
Entry.146:
Killed 15 Turks wounded 2, Prisoner 1-

New Zealanders had 2 men wounded, they did the work, we were in support fortunately the Weather was cool-

We took our Wireless Plant & had aeroplanes to scout. This 
afternoon
 morning their Planes came over, & bombed us well- Killed 1 officer, 
4
 5 Troopers, wounded 16 others & Killed 38 Horses-, I think Col 
Meredith’s
 ------ horse among them.

I got thrown & about 10 horses galloped over me- but only got sand in my ears etc. Honours are easy again- Tell H.L.A. my Horses are O.K.
Entry.147:
Returned Romani

Found a big mail here been very lucky of late

Mother 17/4/16 Day 10/4/ & 29/4/16 Australasians Mills

Dorothy Hungerford four letters

We are expecting Bombs every minute now they like the early mornings to kill things Some of our horses are still missing from yesterdays Stampede.

The Natives left their Camels & yelled, ALLAH, ALLAH, ALLAH.

The best thing to do is to throw yourself flat on the ground.

Just heard 2 of our Horses are at (
Port Said
) many stampeded 7 more 3rd L.H. died today. Your parcel 8/4/16 many thanks even the Rag covering is most useful to the Cook. YE OLDE PLUM Pudding is for Tea tonight.
Entry.148:
No Bombs

We are getting fresh frozen Australian mutton now, but packed on a Camel, in the sun & very often a Camel with skin disease does not make it more enticing, but a change from Bully.

The YMCA is still with us a great institution but their Tent is a rather good sighter for aeroplanes.

Being near the sea, everything steel rusts & the sand knocks the devil out of Razors etc:-

40 Horses still missing but of 1st Regiment.
