Will post this with love, How the weeks go bye-

Sunday after Ascension
Entry.149:
Posted Notes today. As Adjutant gone away sick have taken on Adjutant’s job for the Reg. again

What I would like now is 3 months leave & go home but the War does not seem to change things much .
Entry.150:
I notice a lot of hot air Talk about settling return soldiers etc and anticipation of teaching them How to Cook on a "good" stove.

I think the average soldier only wants peace & quiet in his own congenial surroundings.

We are getting some extra Tucker for the men from the Canal, but the looting is as bad as Gallipoli.

 We are gathering in all the Bedouins & their flocks One little homeless 12 year old, was brought in with 10 goats. She would not leave them & the boys gathered round & gave her biscuits Tea & Bully & would not allow a goat to be Killed. Later she went on to the concentration camp with 50 Piastre for each goat.
Entry.151:
Enemy aeroplanes reported from Patrol & all ranks rushed to their horses half dressed half shaved the great thing is to scatter, lie down, but our native interpreter was last seen in full flight on his fast donkey. We are ringing up Jerusalem to see if he arrived.

Rotten things bombs.

Have posted you an old sketch of No.1 Outpost ANZAC showing – 3 Sections of outpost, I once drew another Sketch which I hoped one day you would have copied but it must have gone down in a trawler It is against military law unless OLD. & finished with but even so keep it yourself as I might get into trouble, Censoring is very strict at present so be careful
Entry.152: All quiet & letters from England one-Laura - one Mardi Ritchie-
Entry.153:
Good news the Naval fight. 

Our Camel men were very funny this morning. In the dark at 3.30 AM, passing the QM Store they heard a Primus Stove burning which sounds exactly like a Bomb falling thro’ the air, our Wireless Oil engine was also working so the Combination made the Natives leave their Camels & run in all directions-

Our hours are long 16 a day so as of old SLEEP is the greatest pleasure-

Last night a poor devil was dreaming of Bombs etc & he yelled so loud he woke the whole Camp-

Thursday 8 June 

No time for 
Football
 now out all last night digging Wells. It is hard to apply oneself to anything outside our job – and "Whether we will get a feed tomorrow" & "How much sleep" I can sleep in any position, any hour of the day having a good Mosquito net.

I found in the
Entry.154:
Our 2nd in Command just got a D.S.O., so the Regiment is pleased with itself-

Entrenching in this drift sand is heart breaking work, each day the Trench fills up with the wind-

Just heard of KITCHENERS death, is it true? Or like Enver Pasha??

Moved out to Reconnoitre in force C. 3.45

Camped at 10 AM Sahia Hear Kitcheners death is true & we are wearing Black Bands-

Left again

Recd letters from England 1 from Laura April 28 Mother Easter Sunday 23rd one from Day
Entry.155:
Camped at 10 AM (Saghia) & tried to sleep till 9 at night when we saddled up for 
Bayud
-

WATER is the trouble always & we never get enough for man or beast on these stunts.

Marched all night & a Rocket was seen to be fired out in the Desert to alarm the Turks.

Our objective was to surround a Turks Patrol & destroy 16 of their Wells.

The nights are beautiful but the days hell & before we got home "We did a PERISH" but not as bad as the 6 & 7th L.H. had. 
We had an aeroplane so bombed their Camels-
Entry.156:
Bayud

at 4 AM a fog came off the coast, & we had to halt, everything was quite wet & we sucked the dew drops to save our Water bottles-

At 7.30 the sun came out & soon "hunted all the Pearls of dew away" By then the enemy had been alarmed & we were fired on by about 80 men with Camels, 2 horses wounded. 

 We destroyed the Wells burnt the Native Mia Mias & started off across the Desert home- via Og----a. By then both Horses & men were shewing Signs of fatigue & want of Water- so we kept on, arriving in Camp at Midnight – 40 miles without unsaddling for 27 hours.
Entry.157:
Very tired & an aeroplane alarm tried us out again. 3 Taubes during our absence used their Machine Guns & darts on our Camp- but no casualties much. 

Thank goodness they did not us while we were out so far, a Stampede there & no water 2 WALK home would have Settled many-

There are advantages in my scribble, No censor could read it!!

Had a reply from Mrs Bradden re Billie’s fez. Our men- regretting the L.H were missed as we did not stay long at Mudos after evacuation. We missed them there & were just too late for the Egypt lot- However our boys have some good stuff coming.
Entry.158:
Hot again today 20 c/s of Comforts from Mrs Bradden arrived so the men are well fed for this week.

I got a parcel from an old Wingalea neighbour soks thick woollen ones Temperature 115 in the shade!!!

One of our Aeroplanes treated us to a good exhibition of flying this morning on a powerful machine I hope to see an aerial fight some day 

1 Gallon of Water per diem per Military Train to Railhead thence by Camel to us-

Australasian from Joe & Independent.
Entry.159:
Before snatching a few minutes sleep must write my notes.

We are off again at midnight neither Horses nor men have recovered from our Past Stunt, but we must do it.

Its these damned aeroplanes give us no rest over when we are in Camp Half the men ride along in their sleep even coming home on Monday but it’s the Old story of Soldiering – a fight is nothing it’s the privations that cut a man up.

Next letter enclose a few strands of Khaki Thread the Housewife you made me is now empty of thread I’m no big sewer but it was most useful.
Entry.160:
Ognatina

"In the shade of the Sheltering Palm" Sounds all right but when shared with Camels- & only a few leaves on the top, the sun travels very quickly around, & every 2 hours a man must shift, or his Water bottle boils!

Moved at 10 p.m. or as we have it 2200, & marched all night & tried to surround a Turkish Outpost- I rode into one of their Telegraph Wires & my horse bolted & threw me I hung on as I did not want to be left & only got a few bruises my horse is cut pretty badly, I pulled down 2 Poles no wonder the Turks heard us & got
Entry.161:
We went over our Map boundary 
yesterd
 this morning but very few tracts, 

we were in the advance Guard for about 15000 men but the Turks retired . Our own aeroplane reported us as being Turks, we were lucky not to be Bombed by our own machine.

Got back to our Camp in the middle of the night having done the round of the clock again-

We have to keep going because of the Water difficulties-

 Got letters just before leaving from Charlie Tyson & Laura the latter never says anything about her own affairs or intentions.
Entry.162:
We have been turning night into Day so much lately I’ve rather lost the thread of things anyway we are back in Camp once more very tired & very sleepy

Letter from May dated April 30th telling me of the Insurance work, poor old girl I’m sorry can’t help her more. 
 Among some Tobacco & Cigarettes issued to me I found a Card from W Kilpatrick Cornallas Peter Pan Cigarettes No doubt about it the folk at home are good to Thomas Atkins & it is appreciated-
Entry.163:
9 aeroplanes flew over this morning our own Flying Squadron going somewhere.

Attended Church Parade Ralph Arnold’s brother was there fit & well.

BOILS on the arms again every Prick from a Palm Tree
s
 festers, flies help this on, but on the whole I’m fit & well.

Russians seem to be doing well now, how long can this last 
but it is not the British Army that is doing the Push, unfortunately but the NAVY is still there.

Our men say they want Moth Balls for their Blankets as it is so long since they have used them, a facetious crowd of good fellows now dog-tired.
Entry.164:
If Day wants to know what I would like a Khaki Knitted Silk Tie would be very acceptable but I fancy she must be too busy at Home & Red +. Hope this arrives safely Love to all.

Over 6 months since we left Heliopolis with our Horses.
Entry.165:
(Rather a sore subject the Pipe LINE so will ring off-)

Posted Notes yesterday- 
Our Pipe line is struggling out but owing to an Austrian Firm having half the Contract the threads are different.
 Some of the Regiment went for a bathe in the Mediteranean only 4 miles away but I have not been yet- It is heavy sand to ride over & men & horse want sleep chiefly-

Off again at 3 AM or 1500 as we call it on another 2 days STUNT to Johnny TURK the men always seem to know in the Lines long before even the Officers get orders; what is going to happen- Like in the Bush when the traveller can always tell you when each Station will commence Shearing & No. to be Shorn.
Entry.166:
Hot as Hell. Marched all night & all day. Horses tucked up wont drink Brackish water heavy sand, destroyed Wells & burnt some Huts took a few Bedouin prisoners but it is rough on the men & horses.

We take our Wireless Plant with us on Camels & when the little oil engine is started it sounds in the dark just like an aeroplane & the men tumble out & until when very tired would not leave them.

Total No.6

Bad Writing & Ink has its disadvantages but it makes these notes so hard to read that a Censor soon gets fed up.

Thursday 22 June 1916 

Am writing this trying to get under shelter of my tunic hung on my sword- no TREES 20 men gone in Sick have had Barcoo & Gyppy Tummy allright, another of these perishing Desert Patrols off the edge of the Map-

Our interpreter says "Ugh" Bully Beef Salt Water WEEVIL Biscuit, sun, Flies, no good, I go home.

We went to find an Aeroplane that had fallen in Turkish Country- we burnt it & took 4 prisoners & carried Engine home on a Camel

One learns by experience Lem is good with Brackish Water- Small Fly Veil for Sandflies which attack at about 9 pm each night- Goggles for the glare- There are very few Ants in the Desert & hardly a bird but apparently endless Stars.

Friday 23 June 1916 

Left Ognatina 5.30 pm for Romani, the whole Brigade fatigued.

My Horses stood it well- met 2 Turks Camel Patrol both ran.

Men’s minds work differently when called after a sleep at a Halt- on the march- One man charged the N.C.O. who woke him- thought TURKS . Jumped up once & ran in my sleep the opposite way to my horse-

We halt for 10 minutes every hour- & all nearly go to sleep, as we are doing the round of the clock. – aviator & observer WALKED to our outposts, from Machine.

I’ve got a bit of the propeller as a small mementoe of a big perish-

Arrived Romani midnight

Saturday 24 June 1916

You might order from Chorley Military Tailor Sydney a Light Horse Puggaree for Felt Hat they know size of Hat tell them to post to my address Egypt

Australasian from Joe 2/5/16

Letter from Mother 7/5/16 & Joe 7/5/16

 "	" 
Da
Entry.168:
Also D’quin Papers-

Please thank all

Sleeping mostly today 25% of Horses on the sick list.

Our Interpreter says "We shoot men like birds" (ie )

We travel in the night like Robbers. We stand to arms the best part of the night & live on Bully & Weevil Biscuits both sides of my stomach & marmalade I’m sick with Brackish Water – I want to go home I & my donkey are tired.
Entry.169:
Church Parade but did not go.

Hear most of our Mail has gone to FRANCE in error, so may miss a few letters for a while-
Entry.170:
Dinner Fray Bentos, Bully Beef- We all swear by the Queensland stuff if we can get it it is much the best Army Beef issued. As for Davies the American it was the brand that had the Fish hooks in it.

Australasian April 29 from Mother just received - & Independent.
Entry.171:
Better Censor latter part of this.

Enemy aeroplane flew over this morning but did not lay any eggs.

From England I got the Morning Post of June 6th giving full a/c of Naval Battle 

 down in the right hand bottom corner of same page is an a/c of the strike of Melbourne Bakers & refusal of others to cart flour etc:- !!!! Reads rather Small at such a time.

At last we hear that some of the Managing Staff of the big Hotel in Cairo have been arrested we always felt that they were d---- Germans. Report says that the engine of a Wireless was in the cellars, Poor old Grannie ENGLAND.
Entry.172:
Another Plane today but no Bombs, I posted you an Egyptian Paper showing how we treated them at ,

 

AL ARISH

Picking up daily both men & Horses, getting plenty of sleep, but another Stunt is due about Friday

Great rumours today that some wonderful news is about to be given out, so we all anxiously await it.

We have no Papers so have to start a few rumours now & again we hope this is not one. Mulga wires are not in it compare with War yarns.
Entry.173:
Our men are shewn on same page.

Sydney Mail of May 10th shows a Pontoon Bridge built not by the Australian Engineers but by the Cheshires, it is our Camp near the trees in the background- & the Pontoon bridge is over a Canal, not the Nile:-

Another Taube over us this morning 4 bombs on Kantara- it is wearisome standing to arms at 3.30 AM & then every time an enemy plane flies over:- First time I’ve seen an Aerial Fight but one battle plane was not fast enough tho’ she fired repeatedly it was most exciting to watch from the ground- they did travel- the Taube as far as I could see went towards the Mediteranean & our machine got hit in the engine. They were right over us-
Entry.174:
Court Martial this morning I am Prosecutor. Poor beggar he is charged with "Asleep on his Post" it is no wonder, & the sea air & night duties, it is hard to keep awake.

Just got a letter from Laura telling me of young Charlie’s wedding it certainly was kept very dark, he has been engaged for a year & 4 months she tells me, such a Kid too- he has certainly beaten his Uncles- rather upsets Braces intentions I expect-

WAR Brides are certainly the fashion even for Boys, what does he know of the World!!! All for the best I hope.
Entry.176:
not open letter.

Posted Notes yesterday hope you get them-

Very hot & many Fatigues More Aeroplanes but no more air fights, it was a great exhibition & once the two great Battle planes appeared over, 100 yards apart- Ours was shot & so was the enemy – but he got away. Our men blame our own Machine Gunners, as the planes were flying so close together it was madness to fire at all- Like Duck shooting hard to judge how far in front when travelling at the rate of 1 mile a minute.

At Gallipoli it was heads down here its "Heads up" to see what brand of Plane it is.

O Circles on Wings of ours

+ Cross on enemies.
Entry.177:
Our Officers have changed a lot since the Regiment left Sydney- they were mostly Bush chaps then- 

 Now we have 2 Dentists & an ex-ship’s steward who told the Mess he used to get 2/6 for every dog the passengers brought aboard the Ship for feeding him etc during the voyage- !!!!! 

Another month begins, & the 
"Dates"
 are growing bigger, in 6 weeks we will be able to live on them, tremendous bunches some weighing a couple of , different to the squashed variety exported & the Sinai ones all supposed to be very good- They only grow in isolated "Hods" or Clumps miles apart.
Entry.178:
Went to Kirk this morning- Saw Arnold there he is Regimental Doctor to the 2nd L.H. I see the L.H. doings are being made public in the English papers, really we are not far away & I hope to go some day ere long- Not far from here on the Railway (Military) some Welsh Regiment started a Canteen for Sergeants Only & asked the L.H. Sergeants to come over- Our men got wind of this & pencilling 3 stripes on their Hats about 300 got over & drank the Canteen dry- The Welshmen now are asking

"How many Regiments we have?

"How many Sergeants per Regiment" etc

It’s a bit of a shame, but our chaps were awful dry.
Entry.179:
Many calls for officers for Camel Corps & Artillery Many of our best Rankers are getting commissions good luck to them-

We carry on much as usual when not out on a 
Stroll
 STUNT, we are digging trenches in the sand, which promptly fill up again before the morning-

Gen 
Cox
 our Brigadier has gone to England for 6 weeks so Col 
J B Meredith
 is our Brigadier again-

Clive Weston a sergeant with me in Africa & a brother of Mr Blake’s was in my Tent half an hour ago.

We hope to go back to the Reserve within the next 3 weeks about 7 miles from the Canal
Entry.180:
This morning I had an APPLE a real Australian Apple- Our Doctor got hold of a c/- from Victoria somehow, & out here on the Desert, they were much appreciated- We get very close to Native on this game, & to dodge about, get a feed, & a sleep come before most things, but all men will come back better for it- tho’ I remember being told often after the SA war-

"All the nice men were killed" however I’ll waive my claim & come back to the old home again.

Good news re the different Fronts & hope it may continue, our Chaps are getting a lively time in France from all we hear.
Entry.182:
Joe	 	21/5/16

		Day		May 14, 27th

Mrs Ainslie Mills & Cutting Paper Diary jumps from March 24 to April 3rd evidently intended to be included in Queen Business-

Many thanks for all

Khaki shirt not here yet will be acceptable on arrival. Think all rot about lonely soldier biz only on the make I get plenty- you know the saying-

"If men don’t love & go to War

"What do they get their manhood for"

-

That Queen business reads very funnily, it must have meant ’a heap of work.

Thursday 6 July 1916

Our chaps tell us from France that they live like fighting cocks there & die too & all arrangements in Commissariat, Line Canteens, Hot Baths etc are splendid, but that the Trenches are not as good as we made in Gallipoli.

The English Paper shew many of the good ships that backed us up at Gallipoli, knocked out but from all accounts the Hun was kept from laughing- & honors are at least easy if not in our favour-

Evening airplane flew over we fired a few shells & the Machine guns got busy, but by the time our Battle planes got here, the Turks had flown- good for nerves-
Entry.183:
My groom went away Sick & he wrote me from Port Said thanking me for sending his Kit Bag, & he said he hoped the Horses were not falling away, he dreamt he was playing with the Cob please tell H.L.A. both going strong also 
Gunshot
.

 

I hope Charlie wont be like so many other Australians who having made their fortune in their country (& from which many of them continue to draw their income) abandon it for ever, don’t talk about it & abandon all affection for the land of their births- We find many such in English regiments- & they always make sure not to be mistaken for Australians, while we would not swap our Felt Hats for all the Helmets-
Entry.184:
Out of the original 1st L.H. only about 50 men remain now in the Regiment, & when my 2 years is up I shall apply for some decent leave- The old hands mostly address all officers, doesn’t not matter whether Major or Capts as Mr. they do not mean anything just CIVILIAN courtesy, but the Touring Officers roar at times.

Did I thank you for the Shirt which arrived safely & the buttons are decently sewn on!! So much stuff is sent here, that falls to pieces with living in it.

Our men are in "shorts" now Gippy made (I mean Egyptian not Gipsies), & with such poor thread the men are always sewing or hanging their pants together with the thorns from the Palm Trees
Entry.185:
We left Camp at midnight & camped in a Hod 20 miles E, we are always getting a little nearer Jerusalem, but this country does not flow with MILK & HONEY but dried LOCUSTS & as for fig leaves, nothing but Palms in scattered clumps I send you a Paper

With love to you dear Mother, & all at home from your loving son 

FV.

Some day I may be able to re-write my experience leaving ANZAC but for the present to us there seems to be too much high falutin going on-

More fight & less heroic tales Wanted.
Entry.186:
Did the usual Reconnaissance the 2nd Reg captured 2 Turks Killed 4 prior left another with both legs broken & a bottle of water, his mates will come & pick him up, there were about 20 on Camels in the Patrol away East. Another of our planes came down & we rescued engine with Camels.

Good news is coming from all Fronts at present, we all hope it may last, but I note the French warning not to be too optimistic. The Pipeline reached our Camp today conveying drinking water from Kantara about 25 miles away- quite an event, as Camels have carried all our water to date.
Entry.187:
Very hot & many Flies & much sand & we’re off again tomorrow night for more Scrap with out Posts- We don’t seem to be doing much actual fighting but we’re keeping the Turks back from the Canal, we have been 8 weeks now with our Camels the only link with 
to
 civilization till the Military train pushes on.

Thank you for 2 Australasians arrived today May 7 & 13th.

A Taube flew over again this morning, took some photos , but dropped no Bombs, our machine turned out later, but after we fired a few shells at the German he cleared out.
Entry.188:
Every tent has a Chameleon these days, they take me back to a School Break Up many years ago & the "PIECE" I had to recite-

Here, one Tommy says they even turn the color of the 
net
 meshes in the Mosquitoe Netts.

A Chameleon lives on Flies so is never hungry here & is valued at 6 packets of Cigarettes.

I had one in my Tent in No 2 General Hospital Pretoria.
Entry.189:
News has just come from Kharel Oasis of an aeroplane coming down, another plane took a mechanic & water & left 
again

The Pilot worked in the sun till he got sunstroke & mounting the machine with mechanic started in WRONG direction, then went mad, & the mechanic drank spirit out of Level both found dead, this happened out from Sohag, which we left ere coming here, so you see the possibilities for Flying men-

7 of our Officers have volunteered to join an Aviation School to learn 
Now office is short

Left at 10 pm for another Desert Raid rode all night- Same old moon that shines over you & Verdun The dawn is very beautiful on the Desert.
Entry.190:
Reconnaisance. T’was here or near-abouts that Napoleon lost all his Cavalry, perished for Water, our movements are regulated by how much Water we have in our Water bottles & the condition of the Horses – very sandy, very HOT. Got some Camels, Goats, & Bedouins only this stunt. Our C.O who is a hot headed Irishman, said, when we were sent to find the aeroplane last week-

"To hell, with their BALLOONS"

"Ill not have my men perished, trying to find their b---dy Balloons"

Each day one aeroplane accompanies us & drops a little bag with a message in it now & again to give us information.
Entry.191:
Very hot & no breeze today

Some talk of a Rest Camp being formed at Port Said & a percentage of men going for a Spell at a time. 

The Tommies get a lot of leave, but of course the Australians are so undisciplined!!! They cannot be trusted etc. Letter from May dated 28/6/15- please thank her.

We have plenty of Bandages with the Red + tell May not to bother to send . 

 We use Adhesive Plaster to cover our Watches just leaving the glass uncovered as the sand is so bad it gets into everything & a Watch soon stops.
Entry.192:
60 cases of Tucker to keep Fit Men FIT, were distributed today. Tinned Fruit Pickles & all those things a School boy likes , we are only a bit overgrown 

We have to thank those good women who went thro’ the ordeal of the Queen business I suppose for swelling the funds to send this stuff along.

Boxing Competition last night but too hot, anything to change the men’s thoughts from Stand to Arms etc etc.

A dozen mouth organs & a concertina or two would amuse them.

You would be surprised on a moonlight night to hear the Music that is knocked out as the men Ride along when "all clear" & going back to Camp
Entry.193:
Battle Taube over this morning & our Aeroplane chased him he went for his life followed by a few hundred rounds from our Machine Guns.

Received Illustrated Papers from England, don’t know who sent em but very acceptable. Could not recognise writing Our patrol is in touch with Turks today mounted on Camels.
Entry.194:
Letters today from Mother June 4 England.

Also English papers-
 Mails are delayed a lot now-, but am glad all’s well.

Enemy plane came again but respects our gunfire & did not drop any bombs.

Altho the Weather is hot I have a rotten cold & feel off color, but only a passing cloud no doubt & have been fit for a long time.
Entry.195:
I note what you say re being "Godmother" to a lonely soldier etc, don’t you think you’ve got your hands full with me- but you were always such a busy little Mother & it is very good of you. 

Clive Weston is here a Sergeant, a brother of Mrs Blake’s.

Word has just come that 8000 Turks are approaching us so we expect a fight in the morning.

All my love will post this.
Entry.196:
We are now watching each other, Brother Turk has entrenched & we are pretty right too, several of our planes proceeded to well & truly Bomb them this morning.

Less sleep than ever now. Cold better. Posted notes yesterday as did not wish to run the risk of taking them to 
Constantinople
. We left a lot of Australian Papers in the Hods or Palms & 
w
 I’m wondering what our Germs & Turks think of Billy Hughes & Co- & our recruiting- politics etc. May have more interesting news shortly- I’m off to England this time if I get cracked.
Entry.197:
Travelled all night & shelled enemy, usual Taubes & Scouts sniping- I could tell you more but dare not.

Casualties I must not mention they were not many but Johnny Turk is in form alright.

Received Mail which went to France also Ointment from Chemist Deniliquin thank you very much- "Bystander"

This nearly = BAIRNSFATHER While we were bustling to get away, the Supply Officer sent a message that all Hoop Iron off Forage & empty bottles (Pickle Gift) were to be collected & returned to Dump at Railhead & not to the Supply Depot!!!
Entry.198:
Dates

Our Brigade is so depleted by sickness (We have been 9 weeks in the Desert) we could not muster up enough.
 We were due for a rest at the end of this month but now with enemy so active expect that will be postponed.

Turks have timed their run to catch the date crop which is just ripening- they can live on lentils Dates & Brackish water & we cannot. That is the difference. Odd Turks are being captured daily by our Patrols They are big strong men, but footsore & not unwilling to be made prisoner, some of them at all events are happier.

Enemy Taube over again.
Entry.199:
"It is a case now of in again, out again, off again "Monaghan"

We only come to Camp for Horsefeed & Rations, scrap every day now.

One of our chaps who got a crack swore & sang out "The --- wait till Bill comes, he’ll give ‘em something"- meaning brother. 

Several duels every day now & we are not so good as the German Planes unfortunately (I should not say this)

With glasses I could pick up the colored Austrian or German uniform on Officers out on the Desert I suppose they’ll get closer yet & well have a big go soon. We can do with all BILLS BROTHERS-
Entry.200:
Night marching again We manage to keep our friends engaged- Not much time for letters or notes, no sleep- as we draw their fire each morning & keep them in check till night, still very hot.

Clive Weston asked for Eleanor Austins address he had seen Stanley or Rupert in Cairo.

Two Taubes over today 
they are top dog till we get faster machines.

Shelled Ognatina last night again, but the Light Horse are doing all the work here.

Infantry cannot travel over the sand.

The Horses eat the green dates well.
Entry.201:
Out again Usual Taubes & sniping We leave one Officer & 3 men to watch Turks all night when we ride home. It’s a weird job I did think the war would be getting over by this, but the end is not in sight.

Our Officer’s Patrol watching the Turks all night played hide & seek with an enemy patrol but shooting in the dark is only wasting ammunition.
Entry.202:
Tired & sleepy but off again tonight, we do 24 hours on the Desert then 12 in Camp- but fatigues & duties have to be carried on so it pans out about 3 hours sleep in 24.

Every halt the whole Brigade is absolutely silent, except for the bits champing & an occasional neigh, the men tie their tired horses on to their spurs & lie down & go to sleep-

The sand is always soft & warm, mud would be desperate so we have so much to be thankful for.
Entry.203:
Out again keeping Johnny Turk occupied- One bullet hit the sand about a yard from me this morning- it was as usual quite hot to handle. Nearly got to England that time.

Taubes spotting again 
We are short of good big Battle Planes & men to fly them.

We lost a couple of Horses & one man wounded today, I dug a Mauser bullet out of the sand 2 yards from me- the Turks are using some of the old pattern Mausers, that make the double report- the bullet is the same.

Friday 28 July 1916

The 7th L.H. ran into a bit of an ambush this morning & had some casualties
 the Turks keep pushing their outposts towards us in the night.

Arrived back to Bivouac this morning & out again tonight.

This is the day we expected Johnnie Turk to attack but he has not shown up yet. I have classed my small Kit into what I can carry & what throw away & am already for eventualities 

Scribbling these notes each day keep me in touch with you, 
little Mother & that far away dusty little town
 – I hope you are keeping well to meet me when I come home once more.
Entry.204:
While scribbling these notes little curls of yellow smoke from Bursting Turks shells are above the Palms-

All day we have been at it- 
The 6th lost an officer & 2 men & we a few
 but (and) we are keeping them back.

I only hope they come on & make a good fight- this endless watching gets on our nerves.

Anniversary of outbreak of War, How long will it last?

Had to dig fresh Wells today to water our Horses as Johnny Turk had our old ones.

If Barringfather the Bystander had one of his men here he would get plenty of amusing sketches- Yesterday when the enemy were shelling us one of our men filled an old Billy Can with Green Dates & when a shell burst he threw the can up in the air the Dates falling around scattering the men.

Our interpreter who is a Xbred is very funny- ‘His heart is very sad for Bully beef" He cannot eat in peace, the atmosphere is not clear & if he can find the man who recommended him this job with the Australians, he will kill him 
directly!

Letter from Mother & JOE
Entry.205: C Fetherstonhaugh ditto & I acknowledged Ligmolene
Entry.206:
I was glad to hear all’s well in the old home & in c/- anything goes wrong I’ll post this today- With love to you all-

I had a note from Jim Ayre he is with our
Entry.207: Reinforcement & should join up soon. I will be glad to have a yarn.
Entry.208:
One of our boys who got surrounded by Turks yesterday has turned up:- He hid in a Bush & lay "perdu" with Turks all around him till dark then he managed to crawl back through their outpost. A good performance & shewing a cool head. Ours are the best in the world when on their own initiative, & the longer one soldiers with them the more one appreciates their qualities. Rough diamonds perhaps but plenty of Guts.

3 Enemy planes bombed our Camp today- The Tommies suffered most each Plane carries about 12 Bombs of 20 lbs. each they also throw hand grenades but no DARTS.
Entry.209:
Night outpost tonight very quiet & very weird. This Desert is fine Sand different to LIBYAN Desert which is stony & you could 
hear
 any one approaching.

Here Camels are absolutely silent- while 
our
 horses neigh & rattle bits & irons. MONITORS shelled enemy lines from Mediteranean today.

I said yesterday the Devils dropped 
no darts
 but in another part of the Camp they threw out 1000s especially over the poor CAMELS, Little 6 inch steel arrows like they dropped on the Peninsular & capable of going clean through a man- 
I believe the setting Flags stick Pins in one too !!!!
Entry.210:
re written – whole page crossed out

The MONITOR at Sea is a great help send a 2000 lbs shell is lovely to listen to sailing thro’ the air & landing with a Crunch. Clouds of dust etc. 

We have been watching the Turks now both night & day for over 2 months & no prospect of being relieved for a bit- they are getting closer.

I Received Australasian & D’quin paper note old JEH & Albert both gone.

I am saving a days Field Messages, which will show you our work, but I dare not post it. We average about 3 casualties a day per Regiment & several Horses lights blown out- it is one of my first jobs on returning to bivouac is to notify Brigade Head Quarters of our Losses

Friday 4 August 1916

Corporal 
Luim
 LUM of Attached Army Medical Service was recommended today for Military Cross for dragging in one of our boys who was wounded lying in front of their trenches his two stretcher bearers were both wounded but he dragged our man along on his own & saved him.

At 11 at night the fight started I got 2 horses shot under me, & got cracked myself on the ribs with shrapnel A N Zealander put me on a horse & with excruciating pain brought me to 2nd LH F. Ambulance section
Entry.211:
Ribs broken & a big gash- but will soon be right again.

The Turks attacked X 8000 strong & 6" Howitzers & they drove us back first but we soon rallied & gave them Hell
Entry.212:
WOUNDED again

Usual dead & dying all around among the Ambulance tents, iron sledges for the single casualties & Sand carts for groups of 4 & 5.

Plain covered with Dead Horses mine among them- I still have one that HLA gave me. 

Wound is painful but not serious I shall cable to you "Nothing serious, flourishing"

Have got to ride a Camel to Railhead that will crucify the flesh.

Their planes dropped 
again
 dozens of Bombs- & smashed up the Railway- From where a wounded man is cleaning his pipe sitting on a dead horse giving us information as to number of Turk prisoners 700 just passed & a German section of Machine Gunners
Entry.213:
– whole page crossed out

Camel Caselet is like in a Baby’s Perambulator & with a little hood I thought I was right, but the ground slipped & I was emptied out- so the MO sent me to a in a Sandcart then in a Goods Train to the Canal then Red + Train great luxury & tinned RABBIT (Australian at that) & landed here No 3 A.G. Hospital Abbassia once more. Lungs a bit sore, but soon alright

Dr MacKnight is here on duty but not in surgical unit Duty & is Anti Tetanus Serum one more puncture but same tunic was broken in by shell- 

-copied
Entry.214:
No 3 AGH 

Sisters to wash me Clean Sheets

Same old CHART I know the Routine well. My 3rd time wounded in under a month.

I hope to go to England. Very stiff and sore but am truly thankful to be alive I’m not what you call a religious man, but I do believe & have faith in some higher power.

I am in bed & looking at Hops Pictures in the Bulletin of Killing Turks make me laugh till my broken rib sticks in.

Our Armenian Interpreters have the time of their lives bossing up the prisoners riding up & down the ranks shouting orders like Generals-
still they come 2500 & 45 German officers.
Entry.215:
Goodnight’s sleep & the nurse washed me I’m O.K. Major 
Darcy
 goes to Australia per SS 
Borda
 on Monday so am giving him my Diary & letter for you- to post in Sydney

As we came along the Canal, the rosy cheeked Tommies climbed on to the train "Tell us all about it chum" 
then when they found we were officers they faded away.

The Cotton fields are in flower now, the 2nd crop I’ve seen in Egypt.

Another batch of wounded arrived last night & the Hospital is full of chloroform.
Entry.216:
re written

 Abbassia No. 3 AGH

The one thing about six weeks with death but I’m much better & washed myself this morning & everything going well.

The Officers coughed it pretty 

Here the Nurses are mostly head ones but are very kind but one is told 

A Red Cross Billy was sent for each officer to use- in it tinned soup Tomato etc 

I put down for a a Shanghai
Entry.217:
Not so good last night but Sisters gave me a sleeping TOT & put me in a fresh Bed & I soon went off- This is a big ward & now holds 30 officers People have brought Flowers & are very good.

News in the Paper is good everything is going right & I feel we have won at last, only a matter of time now.

The papers now give the ANZACS credit for the recent fight- We the LH ANZACS did it helped by the Artillery of course.

Several officers are insensible all night you can hear them rambling about Mother 

Friday 11 August 1916

Lot of men have been in to see me Bushies mostly -Sisters at very top here same Routine & Tucker as in No 1- This hospital was at Lemnos & the Sisters all experienced. They cursed the L.H. keeping them in Egypt- till this scrap came- now they are happy- got something to do.

These are the DINKUM sisters. No 3 General was the Hospital at Lemnos in all the mud etc & no conveniences.

Some more 1st LH Officers came in last night. Knocked out by Camel ride after being wounded its hell in those Casolets.

Poor Lt Ronny Macdonald killed yesterday 8 officers out of
Entry.219:
Getting on A1 going to get up today

Sisters awfully good & I’ll never forget the way they tucked my books under their arms & wiped the sand & blood out. I felt like a kindergartener.

"The same old saw bones

"fever chart the same old aches & Pains

"We bit the same Thermometer in (blooming TYPHOIDTEIN) Bloemfontein

Hope you
Entry.220:
Received your cable Mine must have been delayed.

Getting on A.1 but if I could find out which is going to happen to me re going to England or not. Weather cooler now. A big lot of men leave 
for Australia & England today- invalided.
 is here. Roddy Hyland was shot through the head on the 7th at Katia- Killed.

We are doing alright & giving Johnny Turk a bad time -
but many Casualties
 The Turks say the Germans told them the Australians took no prisoners 

Today Mrs Norman Robertson has actually volunteered to 
nurse
 wounded Turks 

Went to Church & 
meant it today

When I say went 
outside
 to Church, to Ward on verandah.
Entry.221:
Had a Tube stuck in my side today like a cow I know why they bellow now-painful but its now over

The Ward is full of flowers today, brought by the Women of Cairo yesterday- to complete the Midsummer’s Night Dream "Blossom" runs about in the shape of a wee pet Donkey, the orderlies are rearing on Milk.

Had the stitches taken out of my Chest today high up under the right arm, & Im feeling A1, being a healthy beast in good condition can recuperate easily.
Entry.222:
Dr Fay Maclure of Hay is a M.O. in this Hospital had a yarn with him today. Heard today I shall be sent to England to finish my "cure" so as you get this I shall be on the sea. I have had a Mauser bullet, a bomb & a Shrapnel shell. I have yet to be torpedoed. We have some bad cases in here- Poor old Major 
Shanahan
 had his leg taken off- "there goes a good rider" he said. 

My kit Mufti was sent from Cooks today I got a couple of when to open it. 
The Military authorities had been through everything & of course had not repacked decently they no doubt expected to find BOMBS etc & even shrapnel.
Entry.223:
As young Rochefort is going to Australia tomorrow I’ll send these notes with he will deliver-

He has been with this Hospital a long time Young Allanson is here slightly wounded through the leg, nothing serious & he will soon be out again.

Have no idea when I shall be sailing for England probably in a week-

Address c/- Laura please

Love to all

Thursday 17 August 1916 

Doing well & sleeping well

Long looked for letters have arrived 
2/6/16 July 9 &
Entry.224:
Mother Joe Day & Laura Mrs Cotton & English with enclosures-
 also Mrs McKinnon’s muffler & Cap the Bandage she sent me I used on our Trumpeter Sergeant where he was shot.

BHQ means Brigade Head Quarters .

Tell Joe May can do just whatever she likes with Land I told her so- Rash all went till it comes again.

As you will have seen by subsequent letter, I omitted to cross out 2nd line in F.S. Portland I was 
not
 in Hospital before this.

Glad pictures are put up & safe
Entry.225:
Before the wounded came here this Hospital was full of unfits

 

Lately arrived as reinforcements from Australia Sisters say that hundreds are going back out of every batch of arrivals- men who should never have left Australia, some came for the trip, others are really keen but unfit the cost to the people of Australia is about 120/-/- each man, so you see the loss.

 Red Cross stuff is run very systematicly now.

Once a week an orderly comes with a list- Soap Flywhisks Paper Pencils Tootbrushes Powder Literature Paper Cigarettes Cards, Games Sweets etc! & each man puts his name down for what he wants.
Entry.226:
Turk prisoners have brought 
CHOLERA
 with them so every one is inoculated once more. I am getting quite white I was burnt black when I came in, & getting very soft lying in bed.

Woke up as a new orderly fainted & fell over the Surgeon DOCTORS dressing tables couldn’t stand seeing dressing done so I thought it was a Howitzer.
 

Sent you a sketch to replace the one lost in "trawler" but am afraid you must wait till I come home to fill in details & explain-

Was in Hospital this time last year at No.1 A.G.H. (Palace)
Entry.227:
All the boys in the Hospital come & see me & we fight Romani over again, 
they
 know who squibs it & who plays the game.

All are getting over their wounds well- but are indignant at the idea of going to a RAMC Convalescent Hospital instead of Australian.

All the East of Suez Canal is quarantined for CHLORA, so no one can get leave from there.

Went to Church in Pyjamas – as before a Chapel is part of these Barracks.
Entry.228:
We are a happy crowd opposite a pvt has a big spider on a string to play with, on my right another has a violin made out of Capitan tobacco tin & adhesive plaster, & surgical 

On my left a chap with head all bound up, & brain exposed goes ratty & entertains the ward poor devil.

While old Mick who lost his leg wants to know if Bootmakers will sell a single shoe.

Personally I’m getting on A.1. but have not had my shirt on yet & am naturally tired of BED.
Entry.229:
Getting on well.

Last night the pet donkey strolled up to the bedside of a Flying man & kissed him –He gave such a yell it startled the whole ward.

Ere this you will have casualty lists- 
I see the Division from France
 has lost heavily.

Military authorities have searched all Kits at Thos Cooks & Sons, so the four shells etc I had have gone - pretty rotten while a man is on the Desert to go thro’ his Kit.

Sisters have put the Donkey in a bed, with a bandage & thermometer in mouth poor little thing is not bigger than a dog.

Letter from Laura 26/7/16 & one from Rev DAVY
.
Entry.230:
Days are
 Days are 
still
 still warm even hot here, I don’t know how I’ll get on with the cold of England but I haven’t gone yet.

My Chart is normal now 
not so much sore back
 , Pulse good every thing good- my wound was nothing to what some chaps got.
Entry.231:
Parcels from Dotty & Dungalear

Used a blanket for the 1st time last night-

Just heard I am to leave here on Friday 25th catch Hospital Boat for England will take about a fortnight as boat very slow. I go into a Hospital in England & get leave from there.

Feeling very "bucked" about it.

Send you this now as may not get chance later.

Love to all
 – Snap enclosed.
Entry.232:
Cairo’s Church day

Usual Mohammedans work around Hospital I asked one 
why
 he washed his feet etc before "Praying" His answer was good- viz

"Whats use tell you"

"Christian doesn’t 
believe in
 his religion !!! this his conclusion after watching many Church parades etc.

Entrained for Alexandria & boarded Red X ship LETITIA for England mostly Tommies on board

We are crowded but don’t mind, fortunately we have No 1 Station Hos Sisters en route for France & 
not R.A.M.C. sisters

Cabled England I was coming I have 2 months I believe before considered fit-

Left Alexandria at 5.30 pm
Entry.233:
Calm. Bound for Southampton Blind & unfit to travel 100’s of Stretcher cases be good to crippled men after this war. I’m thankful I’m able to get about-

Still we are all merry & bright.

The boat is a blaze of light at night & so different to a Troop ship.

Of course I’m going to Dotty but there’s only one & you Mother I hope you get my letter & photos from Alex.
 Only 4 Australian officers on board so we must be careful per example
Entry.234:
Went service in Music room

 cobalt blue sea. I hope I get your letters in England. I sent a big box of chocs to the Sisters who washed me again here, labelled like the frozen meat – we works-

Not much feeling sympathy on a Hospital ship- just as well but I’ll like to be spoilt by you for a few weeks now- feeling a bit off the result of trying to do too much.

A single canary is in the saloon in a tiny cage, an unnatural life but he seems happy How are yours? Do you still breed the crooked tie ones?
Entry.235:
Off Malta Sister Calvert knows Bob MacFarland’s sister is among the Nursing Staff on board, we had a great yarn about old Hay. & the folk there. 

War news is published daily all’s well Im horribly weak intended to walk about & get fit, but find the stairs enough. Time will fix me up- but I’m bandaged so tight I can hardly breath 
in the rotten foul air below
 

Usual routine, Boat drill Dressings, Sleep, game of bridge, etc.

Can only find 2 Australian Soldiers & 1 new Zealander on board, they were glad to find someone who spoke 
"the Colonial twang"
 & looked like a Convict, with close cropped HAIR
Entry.236:
Sister Calvert says I look 10 years older & she would not know- we made no such ungallant remark to her.

"Gyppy Tummy" last night, I hope for the last time – sort of Colick caused by sand & Bully beef etc:- I suppose- but that is a month ago nearly-

Lovely weather- all the swell.

Just heard by Wireless that ROUMANIA has joined us this will help immensely
Entry.237:
275 miles in 24 hours

Calm Hot night Steaming along Tripoli coast rugged & Timbered:-

Passed an Italian Hospital ship it was near here that this boat ran into an Italian Tramp & cut it in two, easily done in the dark & caused by the NO Light rule.

This day week we should be in England. I must be careful not to tell too many back country yarns there!!

We are over the Spanish coast from here & so on to Gibratler.
Entry.238:
"Cot" cases are beginning to walk but the boat is overcrowded a miserable lot of old derelicts & many mental cases- Shell shock is a Real disease & one feels sorry for a man when his nerves go I’m not at all but hope England will fix it up.

Re Shell Shock- In Lavatory this morning one officer dropped some Hot Water on my toe I jumped yelled out 
a curse
 & my neighbour in front of the glass had to stop shaving but got the shakes again & simply could not finish poor beggar we a HE (high explosive) shell blew him out of a Trench & though not wounded he was gone
Entry.239:
Off Gibraltar. Colder now & one can hardly believe a war is on, shipping all around us-

 

I sometimes wondered in Egypt if the Staff men at the bases realized what was going on – at the fronts. One A.S.C man first time I wanted some Timber "he was up the R " 2 times "out sailing with a young lady" 3rd time "Sorry sir but the Captain is playing cricket.

 We have on board men from Mesopotamia & Orderlies from the Hospital that was in Belgrade & in the action from Servia.

Went to bed with a temperature & a rotten Cold, nothing of the hardy Viking about me more of a black fellow.
Entry.240:
Still Calm but cold this morning & a fog but feel better ere long. I shall be hungry for some sun, I wish I had been sent to Australia now, but the better place takes too long- away from Regiment. 

Majority of men wonderfully better, & more cheerful.

Sea is now a dirty green not the blue of Mediterranean & all the Boats we pass are very plainly branded all along their sides so no mistake can be made re neutrality.

Crossing the Bay of Biscay now & a heavy swell on.

We get the daily War News by wireless, nothing since Roumania came in, of importance, but we are only told what is good for us.
Entry.241:
Cold better Practice Boat Drill last night & one Scotch officer is still shaking badly he was a Shell Shock case & was getting better but the excitement started him off again poor beggar I’m more sorry for nerve cases than any.

Took off outer bandages today, discharge nearly finished 
ribs
 a bit tender otherwise OK.

Church at 10.30 AM Saw a Whale this afternoon & the last of the Spanish Main.

Ours is a big Ward with swinging Cots like Bassinettes tonight I found mine swinging- usually locked – consequently by sitting carelessly on the side & all my property
Entry.242:
Cold better one poor boy died last night, just one day from home!

Sun very sickly, & looks like rain in France.

Expect to get to Southampton tomorrow at 4 pm & unload tomorrow night. 

I have asked to be sent to a London Hospital, & so I finish with Egypt for a while- & when the years have rolled on the Oasis boys may remember the Australians who made glad the hearts of the donkey boys, made sore their (the donkeys) backs sometimes & taught them some of the choicest swear words in the English language

My future wanderings will be of interest to you little Mother alone till I start once more on the great adventure.
Entry.243:
Off Channel Islands

Wireless instructions to go to Portland not Southampton

(Cold better) Reason given submarines had missed course- many sweepers & Torpedoe boats are ahead of us- Left Portland at 3.30 pm with a White Star boat for Southampton so appears we will not now disembark. 

We all expected to land at Portland .
Entry.244:
Arrived Southampton early morning & entrained for London now at No 4 General London Hos Kings College Denmark Hill-

Several Australians here. England is green & happy, apparently. Have called Laura re my arrival & address. Everything very up to date grim & unsentimental here, 
I often think in Touring Hospitals that the tidyness of the ward is of more importance than the comfort of the patient
Entry.245:
Cold grey morning X rayed today quick & lively everything is done, will try & get a photo of my chest for you.

There are hundreds of Australian Officers in England- & many thousands of wounded men.

Expect to see Laura this afternoon & post this.
Entry.246:
This Hospital is in the densest of London.

There are over 2,500 Patients here 24 Officers in my ward alone.

Flowers are very beautiful Carnations like Crysanths & Roses & of course all the girls are the same with rosy cheeks so different to Egypt’s languor & big brown eyes but I like the sun.

Laura’s views are quite English now & I don’t think she will ever go to the Colonies again.

Sorry to hear May broke her nose poor old girl she has no luck.

Went Pay Office more like a Harem the No. of girls employed there & good lookers too. I can understand what a little bit of DRESDEN CHINA you must have been as a girl.
Entry.247:
No word from Laura since.

1 Sister in charge assisted by 4 probationer nurses & they work 10 hours a day ring for orderlies.

These girls are run on a very strict discipline- Open the door for the Medical Officers etc etc.

Cold better but I’m not at all fit some how. Photo of X Ray Chest I hope to be able to send you, but nothing is 
given
 away here. Soldier patients too common and numerous

By
 With the Experts son from Dungalear who is a 
Captain
!! now, we went to see the Battle of the Somme. (Pictures) I just wanted to compare Desert with France.
Entry.248:
(Gum Ck) !!! Went to Ealing & saw Cotton family had Tea & got back by 5 all were well & old Coles full of Munitions work.

No sun today. Mrs L. showed me your last letter dear little Mother I never "commanded 2 Brigades" this would be an Army Cols or General’s command.

I was Camp Commandant at SOHAG, but that is different altogether, only discipline Sanitation & Licenses etc etc.
Entry.249:
Dolly & her Mother came tonight, they want me to go to St Annes as soon as well & are willing for me to be married soon!!! I am sorry Laura is not in town told Mrs Cotton what was going to happen.

Medical Board this afternoon recommended me 6 weeks sick furlough, but don’t know from what date.

Cold is much better & I had tea in town with Dorothy All London is streaked at night with search lights above, but the streets are dark. Expensive place London, everything has increased in price tremendously.
Entry.250:
I have tea & dinner each night with Dolly have seen nothing of Laura or Charlie’s wife- but I may see them later on.

I’ve got a dose of Bronchitis but nothing bad.

Hear all officers in England L H or any other are sent to the Infantry in France.

I am wondering how I would stand the Winter there, its rather a shame to lose Seniority in your own crowd besides having no Kit in England.

However one will see & its no use meeting the Devil half way- Cols Ryan & Mandesley are I am glad to say the Doctors I shall come before.
Entry.251:
With Dorothy. I don’t like this Hospital, Nowell is at Queen Alexander’s Hospital for Officers he has had a small operation nothing serious- he is 
not
 going back to Egypt.

Mardi Ritchie is in London but I have not seen her- Laura seemed to think Mardi had not bothered to call on her but Mardi is working hard & Laura is touchy about those things.

What I should like is a car & someone who knows London just to take me about & tell me all about places. It is lonely on your own.
Entry.252:
With Dorothy. Rang up Sir George Reid, Lady Reid asked me to dinner but I’m not going anywhere at night at all. Just going along quietly.

Not much sunshine & the days are short.

I will send you a Cable if & when I get married.

What a heap of letters must be following me up when they do come, I’ll have quite an interesting day reading them all.
Entry.253:
Neill. Went to A.I.F. headquarters & got sick leave 1 month, hope to get it advanced, I leave tomorrow with Dolly for St Anns-on-Sea & will come back & see Laura when she is back in London.

I am writing this waiting for Mr Neill to turn up he asked me here for a weekend, but as I’m off tomorrow I cannot stay- he has been away at Bournemouth.

My Bronchitis is much better & wound quite healed.
Entry.254:
Mr & Mrs Neill came today to the Hospital to see me. I leave at noon with Dolly for St Anns-on-Sea. Charlie’s wife meets us at the train. I am better & it is warmer. Charlie’s wife is a dear little fair girl with blue eyes same size as Dolly & you Mother. We had lunch & I arrived here at St Annes on Sea at 9 pm.

No one met us as Dolly made a mistake in the day she telegraphed anyway Father is not in favour of War weddings so don’t know what will happen yet.
Entry.255:
St Annes 

Raining hard stayed in bed for Breakfast this is colder than London I think. They have rooms here a gentlewoman runs the house with her 17 year old daughter but I believe the Isherwoods are fairly well to do anyway Dolly wants to marry me & come to Australia. Probably go to Ireland at end of this week & then return here.

Love to you all & some from Dolly.
Entry.256:
St Annes-on-Sea. 

 Much better, but raining.

Quite a lot of wounded men are here.

Breakfast in bed & every luxury. Mr Ish senior goes to Manchester every day so Dolly & I have the day to ourselves. "Pa" offers to rent a Farm & me pay nominal interest in 
England
- but I must go Home & show you "Dolly" & see how she stands Station life first- I would hate to leave you in Australia.

Bronchitis much better.
Entry.257:
St Annes
 We have Hot OXO on the Pier every morning crowds of people there & a 
WOMAN
 BAND.

Dolly is a dainty little girl like Mother.

Going to see old Aunt Anna & Mr Ferrar at Ireland at the end of the week & then coming back here & on to London to an Hotel next to where Laura lives, I don’t think Bruce wanted me at Portman Square somehow, so Laura took a room at Somerset Hotel.
Entry.258:
1.30 Lunch Lady Reid.

Went for a lovely Motor drive around Country parts of Lancashire.

Cold better.

Just got word that Nowell made me an Honorary member of the Junior Army & Navy Club 96 Piccadilly- very good of him.

Wound & Ribs quite alright again but Im soft & "Short a gallop."
Entry.259: Went Manchester met Dolly Grandmother & Aunt all very nice, Champagne dinner etc:- also saw Sister-in-law Mrs Aldwyn Isherwood whom I met in Cairo. Feel as though I had been "Shot at" rather as an exhibition of a future relation.
Entry.260:
Saw Vicar of St Anne re Special Licence Bought Ring etc!!! arranged wedding for Oct 2nd only parents to be there-

Grey day & drizzling- Went to Blackpool to Theatre there saw "
Tonights the night
"

1000s of people a very gay place- not so nice as St Annes on Sea- Had Dinner in Blackpool

Dolly & I spent our day together & are very happy- but I do 
not
 like crowds.
Entry.261:
Went to Ireland from Fleetwood by night boat-

Packed up & got room for Laura for Oct 2 our wedding day Ill send you a Cable when the deed is done- with the one word SPLICED & date-

Arrived 6.30 AM at Belfast calm voyage. These are good fast boats & have only been running a short time as the service was curtailed owing to submarines etc:-
Entry.262:
Ferrar met me with a fine "car" at the wharf & took me thro’ the emerald lanes 5 miles out to Dun- a beautiful country home-

Then on to Church at 11.30 AM & in the afternoon all the Neill & Ferrar Clan came to afternoon tea.

They love to hear all about Australia & Mulberrygong to make me very welcome but it is tiring work doing all the talking.

They all have beautiful homes not many miles apart & know not the word poverty.
Entry.263:
Went 160 miles per car with Mr & Mrs Ferrar to the Giants Causeway- went via Coast road & returned via Ballamena & saw Sir Sam McCaughy’s birthplace-

Ireland’s green is very restful after the Sinia Desert & I enjoyed it all immensely.

so
 Had lunch at Larne where the guns were landed by the Carsonites before the war- you remember the gun running- I’ll make one to sign the Covenant against Home Rule in the North.
Entry.264:
Went Belfast & to the Ulster Club where I write these notes-

Today we lunch with Mrs Ferrar’s sister & dine with her brother.

All the Neill Clan live together or near each other.

Tomorrow I go to "Warrenpoint" to see Aunt Anna.

Beautiful weather but Cold still with me .

Got a wire that Davy family were returning as son was very ill in France- caught train went 
R
 Warrenpoint & saw them all- stayed night with Aunt Anna who I found wonderfully well & bright. Had to cross the Carlingford Loch to catch train at Omeath
Entry.265:
Bronchitis better

Met another cousin Walter Weir, son of Uncle Joe Weir’s- not a bad sort.

Mr Ferrar takes me back per Motor today via Donoughmore or Tullamurry. I passed thro Newry & many old sayings of the Pater came to mind Had afternoon tea at Class Drummond no servants & great poverty, didn’t see Joe although he knew I was coming Frank & Lue both married. Kathleen 17 years old & had little education. the old place overgrown with weeds- 

Joe I believe had been drinking so did not stop long but very kind of course.
Entry.266:
Went to Donoughmore Church & saw grandfather’s grave & on to Tullamurry quite a nice old place but only Farmers there now-

Off to see Mr Ferrars Mother this afternoon. The marshals got most of the old Grandfathers things I understand And the bronze Sundial that was in the garden has gone & all the place is out of repair. Aunt Anna has had the grave done up for herself she says dear old lady- I hope not for many years- she is wonderfully well at present

Friday 29 September 1916

Went to Lunch at Brother of Mrs Ferrars a lovely place on Belfast lock then afternoon tea in Belfast & on to a Sir- Brett an 
cousin
 uncle Lawyer & home to a Champagne Dinner.

Mr Ferrar is alive & well & 80 years of age.

Recd. Australian Mail from Laura. up to July 27
Entry.267:
from Mother 1 from Day 1 from Joe but NO parcel or fountain pen these may come from Egypt.

Letter from Kathleen & May & many others. Glad all is well. 11.15 on Monday will see me a married man-

Love to you all.
Entry.268:
Cold much better . Posted notes yesterday.

Leave by 9.30 pm Boat from Belfast for Fleetwood arrive in the morning & to meet Laura.

All the Neill family have been so nice too me & gave me Wedding presents

Silver Cigarette Box – Gold Pin

"	Flask & Ink Pot

Leather Despatch Box.

They are all Rich 
nice
 people & seemed grateful for what I did at Mulberrygong – one Reggie Neill has his only son posted as missing-

Spent the day walking thro’ a pretty fern glen, full of Pheasants & Rabbits & am sorry to leave old Ireland I am taking a wee bit of 
real
 Shamrock with me.
Entry.269:
Arrived Fleetwood 5 AM but as the Daylight Saving Bill puts all Time back one hour it is really 4 AM Irish time 
but
 to be different but from today all will be the same in the United Kingdom I take train to Blackpool & change there for St Annes-on-Sea.

Much talk of recent raids but a man’s luck would be out if he got a BOMB in this country.

Found Laura at the Grand & had a long yarn, & introduced her to the Isherwood family. She gave Dolly some nice Fish Knives & has helped me a lot, poor old Laura I’ll write again re her later
Entry.270:
THE DAY

Well at 10.45 AM I was married at St Thomas Church by The Rev Mr Ellison, to a dear little girl Dorothy Marguerite Isherwood – Laura travelled to London with us & we are now at Berners Hotel clearing out from Somerset after dinner as the little wife did not like it & our room had not been reserved.

"Jones" does not seem to understand the word STUNT & prints all sorts of variations-

It is an Americanism used a great deal these days in speaking of military work.
Entry.271:
Went to British Australian & put marriage in paper

Answered dozens of letters & telegrams, & bought various necessaries-

Money does go in London but we are very happy & both the wee wife & I have sense.
Entry.272:
Went & saw Laura & also a Doctor to get a certificate re Bronchitis & so help for extension of leave.

Mr Neill called & asked us to Dinner on Friday next-

We have seats tonight for "Her Husband’s Wife" at the New Theatre.

London is very dark at night time.
Entry.273:
Laura to Tea Theatre for 3.

Gladys . Mrs Cotton came & brought me Hay Graziers-

The Doctor Jagger wants me to have an operation on my nose as he considers the bullet I got in SA is the cause of my constant Bronchitis.
Entry.274:
Dinner 
Ferrars
 Neill

Made an allotment of 10/- per day to my wife as long as I’m in the service-

We dine with Mr W 
Ferr
 Neill tonight

Theatre very amusing last night, but Im not keen on it really the air is too bad.

Recd. long letter from Day dated Aug 6 (I was wounded then) & Mother Sorry you sent parcel but some of the L.H. Officers will get it-

Paper cuttings also up to June 19th-

Answering your Question Mother General Chauvel is O/C Anzac Mounted Division.
Entry.275:
Theatre Laura

Brighter & warmer today- Rupert Mathews now a Captain Connie Tyron, Dorothy myself & Laura all going to a "Professor’s Romance" tonight-

Last night Dolly & I dined with W. 
Fer
 Neill & he gave me back the medals I won at the Hay Show with the Mulberrygong Sheep.
Entry.276:
Return to town

Went to Hyde Park Church Parade as I did 15 years ago, then lunched (with Dolly of course) at Hyde Park Hotel.

Afterwards went to Miss Kate Pattersons Flat for Tea meeting Laura, Connie, & Rupert Mathews there-

Was much interested in the lap dog crowd of well dressed men & women in the ROW.

Last nights party with Laura was very enjoyable, it is wonderful how she keeps going.

Poor Aunt A gets assistance from the 
Ladies
 Gentle womans Aid fund - They always want to borrow I have none to lend especially now.
Entry.277:
Examined 

14 days extension sick leave.

Laura here to Tea- Met Harold Ryrie. Had breakfast in bed- Am not returning to Ireland it is hardly worth it.

Went & saw the "Bing Boys" at the Alhambra last night.

To 
day
 morrow we go to Hendon Hall where Dorothy was at shool for some years.

I am taking Laura & Connie to something next Saturday night.

Had afternoon Tea with Laura at Trocadero
Entry.278:
Hendon

Posted letter to Mother yesterday-

Warmer today but throat still sore-

Received Cable from Mother with Congratulations. Am sending you a P. Card of the Girls School Dorothy was at for 5 years one of the best in England & she has the benefit of the best education one could give any girl.

Dined at Frascati’s

Received a bit Mail re-directed from Egypt:- Aug 12 & 19th 

2 from Mother 1 from Day Joe (2 May 19th Aug) Aunt Louie Kathleen & many others.

Joe asks for Purcel he was not there I think- Sorry Day had Cold, Im A.1. now.

Will enquire for David Johnstone. Yes- can get plenty Cigarettes cheap in Egypt.
Entry.279:
Matinee Laura

Neill made me a member of the University Club London, very good of him.

Laura came with news of Ralph Arnolds death- I’m sorry for Lorna.

We go Matinee at the Empire this afternoon.

Later
 very enjoyable but I rather regret spending all this money now but everyone assures me I have married a rich woman (altho’ I did not know it) the wee girl certainly dresses beautifully, you should see the Undies & things & has been very well educated.

Love from Both to all
Entry.280:
We go Riddlers & meet 4 P.M. Troc. to meet Mrs Bartlet Charlie’s father & Mother in law- I find they have a Drapers Shop at Eltham a London Suburb, only a small one, & also run a house agency business apparently well to do & really not bad sorts but 
not
 what Laura would have chosen-

Went to dinner (Champagne) at Capt Riddlers old friends of the Isherwoods & very nice people- I have married a dear little lady Mother, a bit extravagant perhaps but has common sense.
Entry.281:
Gladys Best of Luck

Had Gladys Riddler a nice girl friend of Dorothys to dinner at a fashionable restaurant & then to see The Best of Luck at Drury Lane- good thing I had saved my pennies & only have short time in London- couldn’t keep going-

This morning went to Regents Park for a Blow.

Posting you some Cards of the Giants Causeway Mr Ferrar motored me there. While in Ireland also Dorothys old school now an Hotel & a jolly nice one too

Going to see Mardi Ritchie tomorrow. Expect to leave for Egypt end of this month.
Entry.282:
Connie & Laura Theatre

Misleading Lady
 – Globe- around the clock.

Went & saw Mardi Ritchie at Swedish Hospital, she looks so sweet in Uniform I introduced my wife so that she could tell you what she is like.

Took Laura & Connie to Globe Theatre to see "When the Clock goes around" a pretty little show. Tea at Trocadero Dinner at Frascati I’m getting a bit tired of spending money on all this frivol.
Entry.283:
Delaney comes to town.

Dined with Mrs Cotton No 17 Bus get out at Windsor Road & Parkers to Tea 11 
Cof
 Corfton Road only 10 minutes walk

Met Laura & Connie at the Parkers

In the morning went to Regents Palace Hotel to meet Doctor Eastwood & his wife who go out to Australia this week & may see some of my friends out there. I am introducing Dolly to all I can.
Entry.284:
Got myself photographed for you all at Home & had afternoon Tea with Nowell at the Junior Army & Navy Club.

Lunched at the Criterion & dinner at Frascatis & then went to Daddy-Long-Legs. Nowell asked my wife to tea tomorrow when Im away.
Entry.285:
Laura & I went to Walsall to meet Major Brace a friend of Dollys. Sleeping at the Hotel while I’m away. Brace is bloated, fat, & drinks too much whisky- I do not think he will live to be an old man- Laura is afraid of him.

I return tomorrow.

Brace is Recruiting Officer here & draws a Major’s Pay- He never mentioned the son in law or anyone, Laura is much happier living by herself in London she is a slave when with him-

Young Charlie has made his will.
Entry.286:
Leave by 2.7 pm train for Dolly- Walsall is a manufacturing town & a black one. Went to "Peg o’ my Heart" at the Globe Theatre, with Dolly, she was quite happy at being left alone.

It was very cold coming down in the train but fine.

"Peg o’ my Heart" is a street thing & we both enjoyed it much all about "Ould Oirland"
Entry.287:
Wrote Mother yesterday packed up for Blackpool.

Raining & Cold

Dolly well.

Mrs Cotton here to Afternoon tea; took her to Trocadero good music, but London is cold & I’ll be glad to go to a warmer climate if possible.

Address all letters as before

1st Light Horse Reg

Egypt.

Laura comes back from Walsall on Tuesday 24th October so I hope to see here again-

Enquired for Jones as requested by Joe & enclose all information I can get here.
Entry.288:
Went to Brooklands Hotel in Manchester as Dolly’s home not yet out of the hands of the Decorators & Painters.

North Western Express a splendid Train

Received Australasian from Joe, readdressed from Egypt & Hay Grazier & local papers- please thank him for all his trouble I hope to get a billet in Riverina when I come back as Dungalear no good to me or Dolly Stead is a great friend of J A Campbells so be careful what Joe says about his treatment of me.
Entry.289:
Went to Arnside Cottage & to see Doll’s Grandmother an old woman of 80.

You will be glad to hear that Father & Mother are now friends again & Dollys marriage has brought them together.

Laura is at Walsall but comes down to the Boarding House on Tuesday.

Australian Headquarters are in a low part of London down a dirty bye street filled with Costers barrows etc, not an elevating quarter to employ girls in.
Entry.290:
Went to 
Br
 White’s Home at Accrington & then on to another friends of Dollies named Lanton-

Lunched at Midland Hotel a lovely place 
whe
 in Manchester where Dolly had her 1st Coming out dance.

Met Sassoon there the great Bagdad Jent who used to lend money to the King.

Mr Isherwood is now content for Dotty to come to Australia now that his wife has come back to him- it was 
her
 fault.
Entry.291:
Report to A.D.M.S. Next paragraph crossed out:

Ask re Allotment for Wife- & lot Concession Re pay 5/-/- re Allotment- Also re Passage 

Did all this & took the job of counting Conscription referendum as no 
vote
 Boat sails for Egypt for 10 days left Dolly at Brooklands Hotel with her parents. Poor kid was very downhearted & I expect will come here.
Entry.292:
P.P.C. to Clubs.

Dolly rang up from Manchester to say she is coming down- I’m on a job at Headquarters recording "Conscription Referendum" till my boat sails for Egypt which is indefinite-

Voting so far is a little in favour of Conscription but the majority of the rankers vote against it.

Cold, rotten , job but I suppose I must do my bit somehow till a boat sails.

Am staying at Berners Hotel as I could not get a room at Lauras place.
Entry.293:
A.I.F. Headquarters

Still counting Ballot Papers 10 hours a day- The Soldiers fight a lot better than they fill in their voting papers but so far only 1% are informal & the majority is in favour of NO conscription.

Laura called today at Berners Hotel but only saw Dolly- She is coming to dinner tomorrow night I hope. I may be given some leave after this job I hope so.

Had lunch at Army & Navy Club.

Bad news from Roumanians & the war is a long way from over yet

The Votes here goes against conscription.
Entry.294:
Received Puggaree from Chorley Tailor Sydney. Thanks for sending- don’t bother about spurs now as I bought a pair of spurs here.

Working again Dolly meets me for lunch each day- Meals all dear here- 2/- for Steak 4d for Carnation or Rose & fruit extortionate

Called on Capt Collins official Sec to High Com whose wife was a Miss Brush- & enquired re passage to Australia for Dolly at reduced rate when war is over but Roumanian news does not encourage the belief that it is coming soon.
Entry.295:
Polling Booth.

London is not a place of pleasure in the dark we come back here each night till 10.30.

Don’t mention how the votes go as strict secrecy must be observed.

Laura dined with me last night she is very thin but glad to get away from Walsall.

Colonel Ryan Colonel Manderby were on the Medical Board- English Hospital vote YES

Trench Field Force NO Egyptian not yet here but think they will vote YES- it will be a close go
Entry.296:
Went Church with Dolly Laura 
& self
 came to dinner

Posted photos to both families of wee wife & self.

Returning to AIF office continue vote recording NOs seem to have it.

Rang up Sir Geo Reid & made an appointment for Tuesday afternoon at House of Commons.

Thank you for goggles etc & also Mays parcel which no doubt are in Egypt waiting for me.

Can only find re Sergt Walter Hood is that he is well & has not been injured or sick- he is not in England-

How much LSD have I in Deniliquin Savings Bank please
Entry.297:
At office all day counting votes no- Egyptian Ballot Papers have NOT arrived from Egypt yet-

Fruit, Flowers are very dear in London & it costs me 10/- for a meal for 2 at a decent Restaurant.

Laura seems to spend her time in an endless succession of dinners & afternoon teas She goes out a great deal & seems to have many friends, going out keeps her from thinking a good deal about the mess she made of her life & the War & her sons marriage so young, but don’t say I said so, she has many friends but likes to be "a Triton among minnows" few are Well Known
Entry.298:
Counting votes still Went to see Sir Geo Reid & gave him Sir Sam McCaughy’s letter of introduction & saw over the House of Commons-

Dolly lunches with me each day- Nothing definite as to 
when
 a boat sails for Egypt.

Laura is very thin & does not like going up to Walsall she is I think quite satisfied that No 2 is not a success.

English papers regret the Australian vote of NO after all Hughes’ talk here.

Don’t mention what I say about how the soldiers voted as I am bound to secrecy.
Entry.299:
Received your Parcel from Egypt with Goggles Glasses Razor Chocs Handkerchiefs & Bowel stuff, thank you all so much for sending same,
 they will go back to Egypt with me tomorrow. I only got word this morning that I had to catch a boat at 
Devonport
 tomorrow, one must be always ready, when a soldier.

(Following paragraph is crossed out) 

 Had dinner with Laura at Holborn Restaurant, afternoon tea at the Trocadero, & lunch with Rupert Mathews at the Automobile Club. Dolly of course was with me she is a real soldier’s wife & does not make it worse for me.
Entry.300:
(The following paragraphs are crossed out)

Joes Birthday Good luck to him

Dolly left by 2 pm train for Brooklands Hotel as her Fathers home is not finished- Laura saw me off from Paddington to Devonport where I join my boat for Egypt

Dolly is a good Soldiers wife-

I am leaving my new Uniform Case with Mufti & nice things with Dolly & taking only service things with me to Egypt-

I wonder how long it is all going to last.

 Went on board at 9 o’clock & all night long troops were stamping about 
(somewhere about 2000)
 odd details are on board, Scots, Welsh, Yeomanry, etc.
Entry.301:
On board A25 Troopship a Union Castle Liner taken originally from the Germans and named Huntsend 
 
raining & cold
 
Have written Dolly & telegraphed to Laura & her

The former is well & plucky
 Very few Australians on board only about 
5
 Officers, & a few sick dismissed men for Australia

Plymouth & Devonport are all about the same rather a pretty spot, if it were not so cold & wet-

Goodbye old England I wonder when I’ll see you again.

We are to be vaccinated again against cholera I weigh 13-7lbs.
Entry.302:
A Hospital Boat has just passed us, with wounded & I’m going back "cured" what a funny way it is to see the world!!!

We never are to take our life Belts off, eat in them & sleep in them-

A Destroyer accompanies us

The troops on board are for Salonika
 & we may go round that way & so be 3 weeks on board

We may also go Via 
Malta
 which place I have not yet seen.

We get wireless news of the war every day.

Weather rough & nearly all troops are sick!
Entry.303:
Tremendous storm last night destroyed 5 of our lifeboats broke 6 mens legs, & fractured several arms & 
legs
 HEADS

Our steering gear went wrong & we sprang a leak necessitating gangs of volunteers to go into the engine room & bale, 
as the Bilge pumps were out of order-

In the dark we nearly ran down a Sailing vessels & 
1000/-/-s of £ worth of damage has been done.

I am not ill but feel anything but Cheerful, we are all battened down & the majority of men & officers are very sick.
Entry.304:
Storm still raging & we are only just holding our own-

Some talk of going into 
Brest,
 but skipper wants to hold on to 
Gibraltar
 No Australian 
officers
 men on board but 
3
 Australian Officers 

 I have been in a few bad storms but this one is the worst.

Have stuck to my berth most of the time.

The Steering gear is mended (we were going round & round & drifting or) being blown on to the French coast.
 & we are at the mercy of any submarine I quite expected a - as skipper sent a wireless to say we were in trouble.
Entry.305:
Our Skipper has just received a wireless message from the Admiralty thanking him for his Seamanship in bringing us through the storm at one time we were drifting very near to the French Coast-

It is calmer today but a very high sea running.

The Ship’s order O.C. Troops thanked the men who worked in the stoke hold baleing all night & then Captain of the day. The Tommies are a big hearted crowd & 
the life in the troop deck is HELL, they have no room for exercise.
Entry.306:
Still blowing a gale but things in general are better. We get wireless news of how the war is going but nothing else, writing is difficult, the sea is so rough-

We are now off 
Cape Finistiere
 & the Spanish Coast-

You will notice I am using the end of 1917 Diary anticipating I shall not be soldiering when 1917 November comes round!!!

Dear little Mother I dreamt about you last night & could see you all so plainly at Bronte. It is a great comfort to feel Joe is keeping every thing going & you are well. I hope it was not selfish to many.
Entry.307:
We steered away down past the Straits & are now heading back, a beautiful, warm sunny day, & good to be alive, I am posting letters from 
Gibraltar
 to 
Dolly & Laura
 England but no advantage to Australia, so keep my Diary-

I am very fit & quite ready for the job again-

If I get invalided again I am going home to Australia- 
Dorothy is quite ready for the Bush & I’m a little Homesick to see you all at Bronte
 after Africa I settled down to hardwork & the Bush so should be glad to do so again- but the war is not over yet of course 
if I were offered a good military job I might take it.
Entry.308:
Anchored alongside wharf at 
Gibraltar
 to repair damage done by Storm, am not posting any notes coz I doubt if mail will go quicker than we will-. Inoculated once again for cholera we go from here to 
Malta
 & then a week to 
Alexandria.

Hope to go ashore this afternoon 
"Gib"
 is honeycombed with galleries & big guns & a good deal of shipping is in the bay- all Nationalities We owe a debt of thanks to our Skipper for pulling us through the storm-

New life boats are to be provided here.

Went ashore & bought papers etc- At night 
Gib
 is very pretty with powerful search lights looking across the bay – we have coaled & taken in fresh water
Entry.309:
Went ashore & by courtesy of the garrison Artillery 
we were shown thro’ all the galleries & forts- The huge rock is tunnelled in every direction & has 2 years Rations stored. Aerial tramways convey stores to the top-
 it is not unlike a great big lion guarding the entrance of the 
Mediteranean-

No ill effects of inoculation-

The summit of rock is 1000 ft & commands the 
Algerian
 Coast 
I must not put on paper too much about the Armaments-

Tomorrow is a Bull fight but as I have no Mufti am afraid cannot go across neutral ground to 
Spain
 a big iron picket fence separates
