Gibraltar
 from 
Spain
Entry.310:
Staying here for 2 more days so am sending this as Registered letter let me know if these notes arrive.

Have been made a member of the Mediteranean Club during stay- wrote Laura & the little wife

Beautiful weather but day & night – the Searchlights from light up all the bay- the moon is full at present.

Love to you all little Mother, I never forget you each day when I scribble these notes.
Entry.311:
Posted Diary yesterday at 
Gibraltar
 still here- There was a Bull Fight on the Spanish Main, but we could not go in Uniform or should have been interned- Diabolo is the great game here among the children, & they are very skilfull at it.

At 
6.30 pm
 everyone has to report back & if from neutral ground go home.

We shall be here for some days yet repairing ship I am pleased to see so much of 
Gibraltar
- Had lunch at the Mediteranean Club & saw the Cathedral, an unpretentious building- Cigars & Tobacco very cheap here & good.

Am Changing my Cabin 
mate as he has been drunk for 3 days
 Some firing in the Straits * it is reported we have got an enemy submarine.
Entry.312:
My Registered 
letters
 Diary Notes posted in 
Gibraltar
 may be heavily censored, tell me if you receive them-

We will be here still another day- glorious weather so different to England where it rained every day-

(The following paragraph is crossed out)

Soldiering at home & in is expensive, on the Desert a man can live on his pay- I have managed to keep out of debt so far. The discipline of the New Army does not come up to the Australians & the Officers on board are a pretty scratch lot. 

Hired a hooded Spanish "Calashe" & drove around "the 
ROCK
"
 
Gib
 is only a small place & we have now seen all there is to be seen-

"Kept the Time" for a Boxing Match on Board tonight.
Entry.313:
Still at 
Gib
 am trying to go over a French submarine today We are remaining still another few days here repairing-

REUTER cables are published daily at the Club so we get the worlds news-

Almost time to be wishing you all at home Xmas greetings it seems absurd to think of peace on earth, just now-

The Spanish women had lovely soft velvet brown eyes not hidden by a YASHMAK like they are in Egypt so we are able to see their features- We sail tomorrow but do not know 
Whether via Malta or even if we go to Salonika first or to Alexandria
 where we go.
Entry.314:
Goodbye to the great grey frowning turretted & crenellated fortress rock.
 As the tugs whistled the echos sounded for minutes after & the French blue jackets stood at the salute - & cheered - The Officers of the French submarine were most kind in showing me all over their boats & we drank "vive la France" & entente cordiale in French vermouth-

I would like to describe the submarine but must not do so.

Beautifully calm & sea a lovely blue- We are again dressed up in our Lifebelts- 
but one of H. M. Navy Torpedoe Boat Destroyers is acting as escort (so we are not worrying)
Entry.315:
Did you ever hear of a man called Rooke, he is a Lieutenant on this boat & belongs to Artillery now, an awful outrider tells every one he is an Australian & was born in Widgiewa, I’ve 
not
 disclosed the fact to him that I was born there, he says he knows Deniliquin well, but does not know me or mine. 

I dreamt of the old home last night, & the bathroom etc:- if you have any L.S.D. of mine spend it on a Wardrobe for the spare room with glass big enough to see full length. Don’t smile but I am looking forward to the day when I can bring my wife to Bronte.

How long mighty Father how long! & this is one of her weaknesses- a full length mirror: but I am only joking
Entry.316:
Off the coast of Algeria again, quite hot did some big gun practice with our 4.7 at the stern of the boat.

Understand we are to go to Salonika first, this will be interesting-

Must be many letters waiting for me in Egypt.

Am getting fat & soft on board altho’ there is the usual Gymnasium of mechanical riding Horses etc etc:-

The poor Tommies get little room for exercise. I told you we had many different Regiments aboard. One Scotty Officer at Gibraltar when I admired his Kilts offered to lend them to me to be photographed in- he said my cost 5/-/- with Scotch
Entry.317:
Attended Service by a Canadian Padre, lovely warm morning seems a shame to torpedoe a boat like this but we are now in the danger zone 
from the Adriatic crowd.
 Some rumours that Officers for 
Egypt
 may tranship at 
Malta
, so as not to go all the way around by 
Salonika, 
 but when a soldier "Wait & see" - Just discovered an officer I was yarning with was a mate of Percy Redforths in British East Africa, & German East Africa recently conquered should be a good place for young men "after the war!!"

Rumours in England were that our Division may go to Mesopotamia.

Dropped anchor in 
(St Pauls)
 the Bay
 outside 
(Valette)
 just near the monument to memory of former St Paul
Entry.318:
Re monument VIDE BIBLE it was here St Paul was wrecked, & received no "small Kindness from the "Barbarians, & Mother will know about the Viper that was brought to life after lighting a fire.

Malta
 is a barren island & all earth for agriculture is imported- We anchored & kept very quiet & no lights, 
as the last Troopship was fired at by Submarine in this anchorage. 

It is rumoured we now go to Salonika, but no one knows for Certain-

Our escort has gone to the town of 
Malta
 10 miles away so we may not leave today.

At my mess table are 2 Welshmen 1 Scotchman & an Englishman & I amuse them with black fellow yarns & we are a happy family & worry not 
but I cannot help thinking of the wee wife I left behind.
Entry.319:
(The following paragraph is crossed out)

 You must be careful to omit all military news of value- I heard of a Commander of a Cruiser losing his job, coz his Mother in law put an advt in paper re marriage of her daughter to Commander so & so of HMS ________ inserting ship’s name.

 Left 
Val St Pauls Bay
 yesterday evening & now en route for 
Salonika
 I shall be glad to see something of that cosmopolitan place- A fast Cruiser escorts us, it will be a full week ere I reach 
Alexandria
 or more- 
I posted a letter for Dolly at Malta.
 I will send these notes from 
Egypt
 if I get there!!!! 
The Aegean Sea is not a pleasant place just now in trialling with submarines
Entry.320:
Agean
 Sea once more en route for 
Salonika

Last night another heavy sea arose & the ship registered 41° list- about midnight a very heavy sea struck us- I jumped up & put on life belt, quite sure we had been torpedoed but she is still going strong. Our escort keeps dodging about in front & I think we can trust the NAVY to look after us. Nearly all the troops are for 
Salonika
 & many Officers only for 
Egypt.

We are among the Archipelago islands now, not far off 
Lemnos & Mudros again expect to reach 
Salonika
 midday tomorrow, no use posting letters there - 

Sea calmer, weather colder.

 was struck the day before yesterday & 
500
 lost-

A Dirigible balloon & another Cruiser with a 
Russian & French Troop
 ships have joined us- Union Jack, Red White & Blue & Blue White Red in full speed but a zig zag course, hard to write owing to rolling of ship arrived 
Salonika
 a great relief after all our dangers-

( Following paragraph is crossed out)

The Skipper told me tonight that his Marconi received two S.O.S. messages- one when we were off Folkestone- a boat was being chased by a submarine & the second after we left 
Malta
 but having so many troops on board we had to go on-

A big ship is on the shore here run aground after being torpedoed.

getting wet
"

Have not been able to go ashore but can see all the town with glasses-

I am afraid I won’t be HOME for some time yet

It appears the War Office made a mistake in sending Egyptian Officers to Salonika & no one knows what we are to do here so we await Cable re instructions on board ship
.
Entry.321:
Still anchored at 
Salonika,
 went ashore for an hour, it is a pretty town of many colors filled with a Cosmopolitan crowd of Soldiers & Cut-throats. A big Roman Wall & Tower show the old City 
now surrounded by Tents Stores Haneaks & Soldiers- 
 Olympus is covered with a Cloud like Table Mountain & mule tracks lead over the mountains- 

( Following paragraph is crossed out)

Police are everywhere & it is not wise to express your opinions Many gunboats in the Harbour have their guns trained on the town a Hostile Plane flew over but did not drop any bombs- as usual all lights are out & we are not allowed to even have a Concert in the Saloon
Entry.323:
no use posting this-

Had Service on board our ship- I do not know if this war has made men more religious or not, but it certainly has made them 
think
 more seriously- I know I’m thankful to be alive- 
& hope to find you little Mother as bright as ever when I come home,
 but it’s a "Long Long Trail"

"The Balkan News" reports the death of Austrian Emperor & 
says the Kaiser considers Salonika show to be another Dardanelles

We leave tonight for 
Alexandria
 at 6 pm & will once more travel the 
Aegean
 Sea, among the torpedoes-
Entry.324:
( Following paragraph is crossed out)

Posted a letter to the wife from Salonika but would be no advantage posting to you so send these notes on Arrival at Alex about Thursday next - All dressed up in our Lifebelts again better chance now that only 100 Officers are left on board with 2400 Tommies we had little chance.

I am not sure 
where
 my Regiment is, but will soon find out-

After 6 months have passed I shall try & get leave or a trip to Australia somehow.
Entry.325:
We will be at 
Alexandria
 by this time tomorrow & I am sending you a Cable to say arrived safely-

A smooth passage & we have picked up another escort so should be safe 
now- & the weather is quite warm again.

Communion service in the Smoke room I took part as I was thankful to be still alive.

Rooke’s grandfather was James Cochrane but he knew nothing about the Weir family.
Entry.326:
Arrived safely presented Skipper & Chief Officers with silver smoking outfits- in recognition of their skills.

Ordered report Ismalia Regiment near Bir el Abb

Stayed the night at Windsor Hotel 
Alexandria
 & with a party from Ship heard old Ada Raeve sing- The Long Long Trail a very pretty popular sad song

I shall leave a lot of Kit with the Base Stores- Gezirah 
Cabled the wee wife & also Mother.
Entry.327:
Arrived 
Ismalia
 & got leave to go to Cairo to store Kit-

Received a lot of letters 
one from Mother
Entry.328:
Dolly – Joe & Day, Laura- May Sept 14th- please tell May I did receive goggles, Fly Nett 
 & wrote & acknowledged them. I note she has written a SONG!!!

Address letters as of old but leave out A Squadron I am here perhaps at the Base for a few weeks but do not know yet. 
Also letter from Mrs Cotton, Ferrar & others.

I send the cuttings of Diary onto Dolly they are of interest to me too
.
Entry.329:
Lost my sleeping bag & am in Cairo chasing it & buying more the Railways are desperate in this country.

You may expect to hear of a scrap within the next few 
da
 weeks Al Arish way-

( Following paragraph is crossed out) 

Bought "It happened in Egypt" one of Williamson’s books coz I found my little wife here- she wrote me 2 long letters dear wee soul.

Note what Joe says re 2426 J.N. Bradbury & will try & look him up. 

I see by Papers that Joe has …
Entry.330:
Returned to Camp still minus Kit but got some more in Cairo, met many old friends there But very few soldiers now mostly TARBUSHES

Left leather Kit Bag & washing at Continental Hotel & got an old bag of Nowels.

Got another batch of letters sent back by Laura
Entry.331:
Jack Forth & Day Sept 9th

Joe & Day Sept 17th

Mrs Strong Sept 2nd 

Miss Regus who is married!!!

Aunt Louie- Sept 13th

Papers from Mrs Cotton Mothers parcel coming.

Please thank those you can will write later but very busy I am so "bucked" to get all home news especially at present.

Sunday 3 December 1916

Going 
Port Said
 to look for Kit- as do not want 
to go Desert
 without Certain Articles.

Expect our Regiment to go to Al Arish & have a fight there I may spend Xmas day there! Sorry if my greetings to you all at home are late still you know I never forget you-

Published soldier’s letter in Walgett Paper from local Parson "Re Red X work- "I notice a lot of Pyjamas" made by the dear ladies of Walgett, which make "me feel in touch with you all!!!

Note all Joe says about coming I can’t see how he 
could be doing his bit
 more than where he is- but I understand.
Entry.332:
Col 
L Meredith
 has been in Australia a month 
& may not return
-

Major 
Granville
 now O.C. & his fiancée arrived from Australia & married yesterday. We go 
Ismalia 
 & give him a dinner tonight .

I speak of WE I am at present in Detail Camp near 
Ismalia
 awaiting instructions. Still Kit missing.

Am a bit stiff after riding been so long away-

Hear young Charlie is a Captain now.

Found a Mongoose in my Tent a pet one of the Bengal Lancers I have seen them before
Entry.333:
Inspecting our Mess supply this morning I noticed the Beef came from the ARGENTINE

Word has just come from Regiment for me to go very close to Al Arish you will see it on Map. I am writing & posting this from Moascar near Ismalia-

I am claiming 25/-/- from Egyptian Railways for lost Kit

Am letting tonight.
Entry.334:
Off to Al Arish May be some thing 

Xmas greetings
Entry.335:
Here I am 8 miles from 
Al Arish
 & among the Turks again- Aerial Bombs as of yore & Camel Patrols in touch Since I left 
Sinai
 the railway & Pipeline have pushed on a lot & the main road has been laid down with ordinary ½ X 17X 42 Rabbit netting, five lengths wide quite good for marching on foot & for Motor Cars 

It is expensive but might be used over Sandhills near Homesteads out West.

All ranks seem glad to see me back but the Truck I rode out in was about as rough a train journey as a man could have only sand ballast & always drifting.

I wrote J.A.C on loss of 2 sons
Entry.336:
Usual Reconnaissance same as last July 
but
- Days cooler & nights really cold-

The desert has more life now, small birds Plovers etc but no water beyond the gallon a day & Salt WELL NO TENTS, & issued rations only, I’m soft & fat & will feel it for the first few nights I expect.

Glad to hear that J.D.Meredith is on his way back.

(
PRIVATE
 I should get my Majority i.e. Major inside 6 months with luck.) 

My Bivouac is built of Blankets & Jim Ayres is a Trooper not far away-

Had to cut all my HAIR off close again-

Salt Water & Sand not a good Hair Wash.
Entry.337:
I have 4 Blankets 2 for Bivouac & 2 for Cover Midday warm midnight very cold & 
 Days
 Bed Soks are just the thing.

Enemy Taube over this morning but no bombs

Rode to 
Mazar
 still hunting for Kit.

Tommy Orford from Big Yanko is my Batman again, a good chap.

Long letter from Wee wife- she is well-

Our Patrols exchanged shots with enemy today.

General Cox is my C.O. now; General Meredith went to Australia but is returning, I doubt if he will come to this Brigade though-
Entry.338:
Some of our Officers have been at a Cavalry School at 
Zei
 while I was away- They were told to trot their horses 8 miles an hour, never gallop as the instructors called a Canter the latter pace being unknown

Attended Church Service- Am 
w
 reading C.N. & A.M. Williamson’s book "
It Happened in Egypt
" worth getting - 
The wife was sent it be interested in it

Lovely weather & lovely sunsets it is a great change from the Summers. On the Railway I noticed the same L.N.W.R. engine i.e. London & North Western Railway engines which pulled me about in England- these had been sent out for our Military line.
Entry.339:
Rode on Patrol to some old Ruins on Mediteranean, built of White marble big columns that no Camel could carry so evidently brought by boat from Italy by the Romans. The ruins were an old Church with 
St John
 Maltese & plenty of bones & skulls.

The Altars were tiled with marble slabs held by Copper which now was only Verdigris- (few Beads) Further on a deserted Bedouin Fishing Village, boats Nets etc:- & Quail Nets for catching these birds when they flight. Plenty of old Shark heads 
A Tubs
 etc etc:-

We also came across another old Aeroplane of ours which had been shot down near 
Al Arish
 months ago; now burnt.
Entry.340:
The Desert is at 
this
 its best now & the nights perfect, it seems wrong to be killing men all these years, how long is it all going to last.

Aeroplanes bombed 
3rd
 Reg 
last
 yesterday & they sail over us each day.

We can see the domes & minarets of 
Al Arish
 from our lines.

I can’t give much information as to what we are doing but it is much the same as of old.

Clothing always sticky from the Brackish water & our skin gets cracked & sore.

I told you I’ve got the Criminals hair cut again.

All
 the ANZAC Mounted Division are now to wear Emu feathers in their Hats certainly adds to picturesque of Millinery & breaks
Entry.341:
In regard to Dolly I want you Mother to ask me any questions you would like to know please.

Mr 
Isherwood
 sent me a box of Cigars last mail-

I hear my Kit has turned up at Romani.

On the Canal near Kantara we are erecting a Granite Horse & An ANZAC life size to commemorate the men lost in the Desert stunts, Another stunt is in the wind for the next few days. 

Just seen the Australasian of Oct 21 Wilkinson & Lavenders Sale of Sheep Cairo Wool- Punt- & many familiar faces makes one feel a bit homesick-

The old Murrumbidgee would do me to end my life on- but a man is never satisfied- 
The Cottons want to come back to Australia
 helmets are conspicious
Entry.342:
Today the Infantry are practising their attack on El Arish
 Aeroplanes dropping Smoke balls & spotting for the guns Enemy bombed 2 L H I rode over & had Tea there they showed me a 20 lb bomb that had not exploded 

 Vane, Powder Cap – (Smaller than the Romani ones)

than most 
Later
 4 of these were dropped on our Brig but did no damage-

I watched with my glasses & altho’ the sound is very clear the bomb is not seen till it bursts- before this happens the horses & men have scattered.
Entry.343:
Dolly’s Family Birthday

One of our majors went thro’ the Turks lines to 
Wadi El Arish
 & found 4 good Wells- most useful & good work Sent word back by Pigeons- the message is written on thin rice paper & enclosed in a little aluminium box which is clamped on to the Pigeon’s leg-

This patrol did 40 miles over sand hummocks- Moved on 4 miles closer to the Turks, we see them clearly every day-

Your Parcels of Plum Puddings Fountain pen, milk & Mosquitoe net arrived in 2 parcels from England dated July 22nd – so many thanks 
dear little Mother
 I am writing this with the pen- just the things I wanted.
Entry.344:
When I think of how little a man has on the Desert – House – Blanket on a Palm Leaf Bed- on ground canvas bucket Light- Candle in Jam tin Tucker- Bully beef & the extravagance of London & the grumbling at the cooking & service etc:- one hears the change is the Our outposts captured a Turk spy today, we can see the Turks quite plainly with glasses & the Minarets & Domes of 
El Arish
.

This place is plainly marked on the map. 

Some Gift stuff for the men arrived today. I am saving my Plum Pudding for Xmas day-
Entry.345:
Ten of our planes came along today so things should be exciting in the Air-

Turks dropped a message saying "Thank you for building the Railway we will take delivery of it on Janry 6th"

No service today-
Entry.346: I am always afraid something will crop up to make me lose these notes so will post today- Alls well-
Entry.348:
Anniversary of our evacuation of ANZAC 20/12/15.

Bombed again & a few casualties among Infantry.

( The rest of this page is crossed out)

I see by Day’s letter Mother walked to church & back how splendid & I am so glad to think the way home is so pretty. I felt a bit selfish getting married, but it may be the best for all of us some day- I hope.

Please thank Aunt Louise & K for letters I’ll write when 

The Irish relation said they all thought I would marry K as I used to speak so much about her 16 years ago in Ireland.

To Mazar on a Board re a lost Bag of Mail, shifted Camp to Gererat.
Entry.349:
We are allowed 30 lbs each Officer on the Carriers- this includes Blankets oil sheets, changes of clothes, writing material, Plum Puddings or any extra parcel, soap Towels Razors etc:- & & then as each & every camel is Lousey a good wash & change is essential.

24 hours in the Saddle & am now in Al Arish, Turks evacuated but we got a few prisoners I have a Turkish revolver.

Having drawn 50/- to pay this man I had to carry it on me all the time, so just as well no fight. I would have been down a good hand-

We rode all night & surrounded the town at dawn but they had flown. Two men blown to pieces by a mine on the Beach & other trip wires were found left by Turks to do us damage.
Entry.350:
El Arish Paid all Ranks-

Trawlers & Gunboats came in this morning & landed after sweeping up the mines. The local Egyptians pretend they are glad to see us but they sent up 2 pigeons as soon as we entered.

Infantry & Guns arrive today but the 1st L H had the honor of being the first to enter the town.

Already ships are arriving with horsefeed & Rations. The railway will follow. I am back in my old job as Adjutant.

The Anzac Division attack MAGDHABA tomorrow a stronghold of the Turks.
Entry.351:
I am watching the Battle of MAGDHABA we are in support- marched at night all the mounted men 3 
Brigades
 of LH & a Brigade of Camels & Battery- 28 miles over sand dunes all night nothing along a road- We have the Turks surrounded & I’ll tell you later the result-

Our Planes led off by bombing the enemy, now the 18 pounders are firing they have 8 guns.

3pm the C.O. self & C Squadron attacked on right & half an hour it was all over they surrendered- about 300 4 guns & we took over the garrison- their Commandant got away but we got all their stores & Camels-

Camped again without Blankets & it was a weird night gathering wounded.
Entry.352:
Magdhaba

Xmas eve & our job is to help clean up the Battlefield collect rifles & ammunition Bury the dead, succour the wounded & burn what we cannot take away- Any amount of loot- Oil engine pumps ordnance. 

Two Armenian Doctors help our own-

We go back to El Arish today-

This fight about finishes the Turks in SINIA for some time anyway- 

I just got back in time to help capture the guns that wounded our men in August.

3rd night without a Blanket freezing cold but all hands cheerful at result of Battle.
Entry.353:
XMAS DAY
 El Arish

Got back midnight with 4 Guns 1000 Rifles 100000 rounds ammunition, Telephone instruments Oil engine, Machine Gun parts. Prisoners sent away by Boat. We buried 96 Turks yesterday Our casualties were alright.

Burnt Wagons Huts & every thing else burnt & after smashing Pumps evacuated with Loot-

Such is War including 2 little Bedouin children of about 4 & 5 deserted- these we fed & put with our sick & wounded.

Turks had plenty Tucker & a good stronghold- they have a great respect for our felt hatted Bushies- I collected Papers, Photos, stamps & such like stuff & have sent all to Hd Qts to be interpreted-

We have so little it was hard lines to have to burn Rations Horsefeed etc but can’t carry much on Camels

Entry.355:
Wet last night but the sandy soil is not as bad as France-

Quite a lot of shipping is going on here now, We hope for better rations soon-

Posted letters by Camel escort yesterday, hope they arrive.

Hungry Armenians who have been working for the Turks come in all day- All Christians now!!! No doubt our success will help the Sheik of Mecca.

We are bombed daily but High Explosives in sand do little damage except to Horses, & a man is not supposed to have any here.

I can hear a Turkish gramophone we captured playing Casino airs from the Ottoman City. Oil sheets were the best Loot
Entry.356:
Rum issued last night, the first for many days- Bought a very poor fowl & 2 Eggs for 2/- from the Natives in El Arish.

Forage & Rations are being landed in surf boats from Steamers outside- No bay or harbour of any sort. The Navy had bombarded the Fort to ruins- reminds one of ANZAC. Tin of Kero from Turks proves to be Cylinder oil but it helps boil the Billy & a pair of gloves from a Turkish Officer are keeping my hands warm. I was 
not
 away Collecting Papers & Documents perhaps of Military value 
to get much LOOT
.
Entry.357:
This land is different to Egypt as we know it. Here it RAINS, in fact has been for 4 days, last night an extra heavy shower one of the men sang out QUACK! QUACK,!!! & not another sound was heard.

Like me buying my Fowl holding out 5 Piastres & saying "Chuck Chuck" only language available.

But in the dead of night it showed the men were right -of course very bucked at their success.

Gen 
Chetwynde
 paraded us & did the usual about our wonderful cavalry work makes the Tommies a bit jealous, but they always do their bit & certainly in France, 
a big bit
.
Entry.358:
Rain again. Parcels arrived per Camels Cigars from Father in law Tucker- Miss Pagors now Mrs Stoyles & some from Mother sent back from England by Laura.

Papers too but we are off 
in
 this morning on another 2 days stunt I hope more Captives. Some of the parcels have been following me since April. 

The Native Camels are being shorn with big rough scissors about 4 inches of Hair comes off & is made into very durable Tent Coverings Rope, & mats by the natives-

Small Pox has broken out in El Arish but we are camped on the Hills.
Entry.359:
Raining still

Ring out the War Ring in Goodwill to all man kind!!! I hope I & my wife may be with you ere another year comes round.

Did a Perish last night 5 miles from the Turkish frontier-

Dug down 2 ft to the dry sand & with my feet in a nosebag & one blanket tried to sleep- You will hear of another scrap in a few days-

Am posting you some Stamps photos etc got from Magdhaba Turks bivouacs, with these Notes - & all good wishes for the New Year- We arrived back from stunt at sundown & Iv’e shaved washed & put on clean clothes for the New Year. 
I handed most into Brigade but kept a few for you. Someone may translate
.
